rows.title: Who Took My Shoe?

description.eng: Jabulani has lost his school shoe. He can’t find it anywhere. Where can it be?

licence.eng: © Book Dash, 2022. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: "Come, Jabulani," Ma says."Why aren’t you ready? You’ll be late for school." "I can’t find my shoe," says Jabulani.

text_2_left.eng: "Did you look under your bed?" says Ma. "It’s not under my bed," Jabulani says.

text_2_right.eng: "Did you look in the wardrobe?" Ma asks. "Yes, it’s not in the wardrobe."

text_3_left.eng: "I know where your shoe is," giggles Jabulani’s sister Lungi. "Where?" Jabulani asks. "I’m not telling you!" says Lungi

text_4_left.eng: "Why would someone take one shoe when they’ve got two feet?" says Lungi.

text_4_right.eng: "I don’t know. Maybe they’ve hidden it to make me cross."

text_5_left.eng: "Did you take my shoe?" he asks Lungi.

text_5_right.eng: "No," says Lungi, "your shoes are too big for me."

text_6_left.eng: "Did you take my shoe?" Jabulani asks Fruit Juice the Dog.

text_6_right.eng: She smiles her big dog smile at him and wags her tail.

text_7.eng: "Maybe a bird picked it up and flew away with your shoe," laughs Lungi.

text_8.eng: "Maybe a monkey took it and left it up in a tree, " says Jabulani.

text_9.eng: "Don’t worry, we’ll find your shoe," says Ma. "Everyone look for Jabulani’s shoe." But the shoe is nowhere to be found.

text_10.eng: "It’s all right," says Ma. "You can wear your takkies to school today."

text_11.eng: Lungi comes rushing into the kitchen with a big smile on her face. "I know where your shoe is," she shouts. "Come and see."

rows.author: Sarah McGregor
rows.title: I don't want to go to sleep

title.eng: I don't want to go to sleep

description.eng: Nandi doesn’t want to go to sleep. No way! She wants to go on an adventure. Join Nandi as she lets her imagination run wild and free.

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_right.eng: "I don’t want to go to sleep!"

text_2_right.eng: "I ... don’t ... want ... to ... go ... to ... sleep."

text_3_left.eng: "I want more supper. Another book! Just one more song?" "Goodnight, Nandi."

text_3_right.eng: "I don’t want to go to sleep!"

text_4_left.eng: "MAMA! ...I need a glass of water. Please? Please." "It’s time to go to sleep now. Goodnight, Nandi."

text_4_right.eng: "I DON’T WANT TO GO TO SLEEP!"

text_5_left.eng: Mama sighs: "What about an adventure? Do you want an adventure?"

text_6_left.eng: "Do you want to creep through the jungle on the trail of the fearsome hippocrocoturtleduck?"

text_7.eng: "I want to fly across the sky! Leap from star to star! Fill my pockets with stardust!"

text_8.eng: "I want a Nandi-sized glass submarine to see the creatures at the bottom of the ocean! And a pet giant squid to do water ballet there with me!"

text_9.eng: "I want to build myself a pair of butterfly wings and zoom to the roof of the sky where I’ll see all the world and everything in it!"

text_10.eng: "Look here, Nandi. Here is your very own adventure boat. It’s waiting to take you wherever you want to go. See, put your head here...that’s right...and I’ll just tuck you in...there we go...now, off you go! Adventure awaits ..."

text_11.eng: "Goodnight, Nandi."

text_12.eng: Draw your dreams here.

rows.title: Scared Tumi

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: "What if there’s a monster under my bed?" Tumi is scared. Mama tries to show him that everything is okay.

licence.eng: © Book Dash, 2016. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: My name is Tumi and I am scared.

guidance_1_a.eng: Say, “Mmh, the boy looks scared. I wonder what could have happened?

text_2.eng: Mama says it’s okay to be scared. "Everybody gets scared."

guidance_2_a.eng: Say, “Sometimes I feel scared” Ask, “Have you ever felt scared? what do you think made you feel that way?”

text_3.eng: What if there is a monster under my bed?

guidance_3_a.eng:
Say, “Oh no, is that a monster under the bed? What is the boy going to do?”

Ask, “show me what you do when you feel scared?”

text_4.eng: "Then I will tell it to go away and NEVER come back."

guidance_4_a.eng: Ask, “who do you go to when you feel scared? How do you feel when you are with them?”

text_5.eng: What if there are eyes in the bath tub drain?

guidance_5_a.eng:
Say, "Oh no! Not another monster in the bathtub!”
Then point to each item and say, "This is a bathtub (wait for the child to repeat). This is a tap (wait for the child to repeat). These are tiles (wait for the child to repeat). These are monster eyes! (wait for the child to repeat).”

text_6.eng: "Then your big sister, Kamo, will pull you out of the bath."

guidance_6_a.eng:
Ask, “Can you tell me what a bathtub is used for?” If the child does not know then help them by saying, “a bathtub is used to bath.”

Say, “now tell me, do you enjoy bathing? Why or why not?”

text_7.eng: What if a whale swallows me at the beach?

guidance_7_a.eng:
Say, “Oh no, is that a whale at the beach? 

Ask, “how would you react if you saw a whale? why?

text_8.eng: "Then Kamo and I will swim into the whale’s mouth to rescue you."

guidance_8_a.eng:
Point at the picture of the boy in a whale and say, “oh no, the whale swallowed a boy. What are we going to do? 

Again say, “look, i think they are going to rescue the boy.”

Ask, “how do you think the boy feels seeing them? Why?

text_9.eng: What if I can’t sing ABC and the other kids laugh at me?

guidance_9_a.eng:
Ask, “how many people do you see in this picture? How many have hair?  What color is their clothes? Who is the tallest?”

Say, “guess what, the tallest is the teacher.”

text_10.eng: "Then Teacher Jill will help you remember."

guidance_10_a.eng: Ask, “Do you have a teacher? Who is your teacher?”

text_11.eng: What if I'm scared of going to the dentist tomorrow?

guidance_11_a.eng:
Say, "Look! This looks like a dentist's room. Do you know what a dentist is?"
"Imagine your teeth are like little building blocks in your mouth. A dentist is a special helper who makes sure those building blocks stay strong and clean! They help keep your smile healthy and happy!”

text_12.eng: "I will be right there holding your hand." Everybody gets scared. Mama says it’s okay.

guidance_12_a.eng:
Say, "Look! The boy is smiling! Maybe he's not scared anymore."
Then, smile really big and say, "See? This is my smile! It makes me happy to smile!"  Then ask: "Now you show me your smile! How does it feel when you smile?"

rows.title: Mom's Red Coat

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: Mom needs to go away for work. I’ll miss her. Will it help if she leaves her red coat with me?

licence.eng: © Book Dash, 2022. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: I love Mom’s coat! It’s red and long and warm. And it smells like Mom!

guidance_1_a.eng: Ask: what are they doing? What colour is her coat?

text_2.eng: I love doing things with Mom! We picnic outside. She hugs me when I come home from school. We work in the garden. At night, she holds me tight until I fall asleep.

guidance_2_a.eng: Describe what you see, or ask your child to tell you what they see.

text_3.eng: "Good news!" says Mom. "I found a job! I will be away all week, but I’ll come home on weekends!"

guidance_3_a.eng: Mimic actions from the pictures or story, like the mom being excited.

text_4.eng: "Who will hold me at night, Mom?" "Who will hug me, picnic with me, garden with me?"

guidance_4_a.eng: Talk about what the characters might be thinking or feeling. Ask: how does the boy feel? Why do you think he feels that way?

text_5.eng: "I can see that you are sad. I will leave my red coat here with you." "When you see it, remember that I love you and I’m coming back."

guidance_5_a.eng: To help your child understand, explain what is happening. Say: Look, the mom has to go, but she is leaving her red coat behind for her son to comfort him.

text_6_left.eng: I drag the red coat outside – it’s my picnic blanket! It feels like Mom is with me.

guidance_6_a.eng: Ask: Where is the boy? Where is his mom’s red coat? What is he doing?

text_7.eng: I am sad that Mom’s not waiting at the door when I come home. I put on her coat. It’s warm and it smells like her. It feels like a hug!

guidance_7_a.eng: Use descriptive words to talk about the pictures. Say: Look, he is wearing his mom’s red coat. He is holding a paint brush in one hand and a picture in the other hand.

text_8.eng: I help Gogo in the garden. The long coat on the branch scares away the chickens! It feels like Mom is gardening with us. Oops! Mud!

guidance_8_a.eng: Ask: Where is the red coat now? What animals can you see under the tree? Do they look the same, or are they different? Are they going in the same direction or in opposite directions?

text_9.eng: When it’s dark, I miss Mom most. Gogo covers me with her warm coat. It feels like Mom is holding me as I fall asleep. Oops! Cookie crumbs!

guidance_9_a.eng: Ask: Where is the red coat now? What is the boy doing? Why do you think he is doing that? Do you think he might be missing his mom?

text_10.eng: Mom’s red coat is warm and smells like...paint, juice, mud, and cookie crumbs! Oops! We need to wash it!

guidance_10_a.eng: Say: Look, the red coat is hanging on the washing line. Ask: Why do you think they washed the coat? What else is hanging on the washing line? How many socks can you see?

text_11.eng: The wind blows the red coat off the washing line...up into the air! It flies over the fence! It flies over the taxi! Oops! Who did the coat fall on?

guidance_11_a.eng: Say: Look, the wind blew the red coat away. Ask: who do you think is under the coat? Why do you think so?

text_12.eng: I run and grab it! "Found you, coat!" The red coat smells like Mom again. "Oh!" "Found you, Mom! You’re back!"

guidance_12_a.eng: Demonstrate the emotions from the story. Say in a happy voice: hooray! His mom is back! Ask: how do you think he is feeling now?

rows.text_2: I love doing things with Mom! We picnic outside. She hugs me when I come home from school. We work in the garden. At night, she holds me tight until I fall asleep.
rows.guidance_2_a: Describe what you see, or ask your child to tell you what they see.
rows.text_3: "Good news!" says Mom. "I found a job! I will be away all week, but I’ll come home on weekends!"
rows.guidance_3_a: Mimic actions from the pictures or story, like the mom being excited.
rows.text_4: "Who will hold me at night, Mom?" "Who will hug me, picnic with me, garden with me?"
rows.guidance_4_a: Talk about what the characters might be thinking or feeling. Ask: how does the boy feel? Why do you think he feels that way?
rows.text_5: "I can see that you are sad. I will leave my red coat here with you." "When you see it, remember that I love you and I’m coming back."
rows.guidance_5_a: To help your child understand, explain what is happening. Say: Look, the mom has to go, but she is leaving her red coat behind for her son to comfort him.
rows.guidance_6_a: Ask: Where is the boy? Where is his mom’s red coat? What is he doing?
rows.guidance_7_a: Use descriptive words to talk about the pictures. Say: Look, he is wearing his mom’s red coat. He is holding a paint brush in one hand and a picture in the other hand.
rows.guidance_8_a: Ask: Where is the red coat now? What animals can you see under the tree? Do they look the same, or are they different? Are they going in the same direction or in opposite directions?
rows.guidance_9_a: Ask: Where is the red coat now? What is the boy doing? Why do you think he is doing that? Do you think he might be missing his mom?
rows.guidance_10_a: Say: Look, the red coat is hanging on the washing line. Ask: Why do you think they washed the coat? What else is hanging on the washing line? How many socks can you see?
rows.guidance_11_a: Say: Look, the wind blew the red coat away. Ask: who do you think is under the coat? Why do you think so?
rows.guidance_12_a: Demonstrate the emotions from the story. Say in a happy voice: hooray! His mom is back! Ask: how do you think he is feeling now?

rows.title: When Will Amma Be Back?

description.eng: Roja’s mother leaves for work early in the day. She promises to be back by bedtime. What will Roja do all day without Amma?

licence.eng: © Pratham Books, 2018. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: Roja is sad. Amma is going to work. "I will be back before bedtime, kannamma," says Amma.

text_2.eng: "But at what time?" asks Roja. "At exactly 9 o’clock tonight," replies Amma. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 6 o’clock in the morning.

text_3.eng: "I want Amma to give me milk. Not you!" says Roja to Appa. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 8 o’clock in the morning.

text_4.eng: "Let’s buy potatoes, Thaatha!" says Roja. "But we had potatoes just yesterday. How about brinjal today?" Thaatha asks. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 10 o’clock in the morning.

text_5.eng: "Paati, let’s eat. Thaatha is making pappadam!" Roja yells. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 1 o’clock in the afternoon.

text_6.eng: Honk! Honk! Roja’s Akka is back from school. "Paati says I will go to school with you after this summer. Won’t that be fun,Akka?" says Roja, excitedly. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 3 o’clock in the afternoon.

text_7.eng: "It’s time to go home, Roja," Appa calls out. "Just one last time!" shouts Roja. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 5 o’clock in the evening.

text_8.eng: "Selvi, eat your dosai quickly! Only then will you become big and strong," says Roja. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 7 o’clock at night.

text_9.eng: "And so, when the cap-seller threw down his cap, the monkeys threw their caps down too... "

text_10.eng: "AMMMAAAA!" Roja shouts. "What did you do all day, Roja?" Amma asks. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is almost 9 o’clock at night.

text_11.eng: "I had a lot of fun today, Amma! Appa fed me breakfast. I bought brinjal with Thaatha. He made pappadam for lunch.

text_12.eng: I picked up Akka from the school van. I played in the park. I fed Selvi dinner. Appa told me a story and now you are back!" Roja says, with a wide smile.

text_13.eng: Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 9 o’clock at night!

text_14.eng:
**My Day**
Here are some things that Roja does at different times of the day. What did you do at the same time yesterday? Draw pictures of yourself doing these different things on a piece of paper.
1. Roja eats breakfast at 8 o’clock. What did you do at 8 o’clock yesterday?
2. Roja goes shopping at 10 o’clock. What did you do at 10 o’clock yesterday?
3. Roja eats lunch at 1 o’clock. What did you do at 1 o’clock yesterday?

text_15.eng:
4. Roja picks up Akka from the school van at 3 o’clock. What did you do at 3 o’clock yesterday?
5. Roja plays in the park at 5 o’clock. What did you do at 5 o’clock yesterday?
6. Roja feeds Selvi at 7 o’clock. What did you do at 7 o’clock yesterday?

rows.title: The Bee and the Elephant

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover. Ask: What do you see? What is the bee doing? Where is the bee lying down?”

description.eng: An elephant tries to help a little lost bee find his home. Is it the nest? The cave? Where does he live?

licence.eng: © Room to Read, 2015. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: "I am lost," said Little Bee. "I cannot find my home!" "Can you please help me, Mr. Elephant?"

guidance_1_a.eng: Say: “Oh no, I think the bee is lost, it is all alone.” Ask: “Can you tell how the bee is feeling? Why do you think so? Who do you see behind the bee?”

text_2.eng: "Is this nest your home, Little Bee?" the elephant asked.

guidance_2_a.eng: Say: “Look, the bee is sitting on the elephant's trunk! What is the elephant doing? Where is he putting the bee? Why do you think he is putting him there?”

text_3.eng: "Oh no!" cried Little Bee. "This is a bird’s home."

guidance_3_a.eng: Ask: “How many animals can you see? Can you name them? Which one is the biggest? Which one is the smallest?”

text_4.eng: "Is this cave your home?" asked the elephant.

guidance_4_a.eng: Say: “Look, there is the cave. Where could the elephant be taking the bee?” Ask: “Would you go to the cave?”

text_5.eng: "Oh no! This is a bat’s home."

guidance_5_a.eng: Say: “Look, the elephant and bee are running away!” (mimic the sound and the action). Ask: “What are they running from? Can you show me how you  can run?”

text_6.eng: "Is this hive your home, Little Bee?"

guidance_6_a.eng: Say: “Wala, there is a beehive! Finally, the bee is home!” Ask: How do you think the bee feels now? How do you think the elephant feels? How do you feel when you get home? Why do you feel like that?”

text_7.eng: "Oh yes!" said Little Bee happily. "This is my home."

guidance_7_a.eng: Use a picture to help your child count. Ask: “How many bees can you see? How many eyes do you see? Now count your eyes, how many eyes do you have?”

text_8.eng: "Thank you for helping me, Mr. Elephant."

guidance_8_a.eng: Say: “Look, the bees, the bird and the bats are flying. What sound do bees make when they fly? And what about birds?” Ask: “How many bees can you see? And how many bats can you see?”

guidance_9_a.eng: Ask: “What do you think about this story? How would you feel if you were in the story? What would you have done if you were the elephant?”

rows.author: Philippa Namutebi Kabali-Kagwa
rows.title: Katiiti’s Song

description.eng: Every day, Katiiti’s mother calls her with a beautiful song. One day, a crafty gorilla tries to sing as sweetly as her mother.

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1.eng: Katiiti lived in a village next to a forest.

text_2.eng: She loved playing in the forest. Maama told her to be careful.

text_3.eng: Every day Maama would sing their special song to call her.

text_4.eng: One day, Katiiti bumped into a gorilla.

text_5.eng: She ran and hid in a cave.

text_6.eng: Gorilla came and sang Maama’s song in a gruff voice.

text_7.eng: Gorilla ate lots of bananas to make his voice sweeter.

text_8.eng: Gorilla sang sweetishly.

text_9.eng: Gorilla went away and ate lots of honey to make his voice even sweeter.

text_10.eng: Gorilla sang as sweetly as Maama.

text_11.eng: Maama came just in time to chase away Gorilla.

text_12.eng: Katiiti and Maama sang all the way back home.

rows.author: Elana Bregin
rows.title: A Beautiful Day

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: It’s a beautiful day for a picnic. Everyone wants to join in the fun.

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: "What a beautiful day," says Mom. "Wake up Nicholas."

guidance_1_a.eng: Say: “Look, the boy just woke up.” Ask: “What do you think the mother is saying to the boy? Can you tell me how the boy is feeling? What is the baby pointing to? Who else sees what the baby sees?”

text_2_left.eng: "It’s a lovely day," says Dad. "Let’s have a picnic by the river."

text_2_right.eng: "Can my friend Jacob come?" asks Nicholas.

guidance_2_a.eng: Say: “Wow, it's such a beautiful day.” Ask: What are they eating for breakfast? What did you eat for breakfast this morning? What can you see through their window? And what can you see through our window?”

text_3_left.eng: "Don’t forget me. I love picnics!" says Donkey. "And me. I want to come too!" says Dog.

guidance_3_a.eng: Ask: “How many children can you see? How are they feeling? Can you name all the animals? How many birds can you see? Which bird is flying the highest? And which bird is flying the lowest?”

guidance_4_a.eng: Ask: “Where do you think they are going? Who is walking in the front? And who is walking at the back?”

text_5_left.eng: "I’ll race you to that tree," Nicholas says.

guidance_5_a.eng: Say: “Now the boy is pointing at the tree, I think they are getting ready to see who can reach the tree first. Ready, set, go!!!!!” Ask your child: “Who do you think will win the race? Let’s go to the next page to find out.”

text_6.eng: "I won, I won," says Donkey. "Not fair," says Nicholas. "You’ve got four legs."

guidance_6_a.eng: Say: “Hurray! The monkey won the race”. Ask: Who looks tired? Why do you think he is tired?”

text_7_left.eng: "Look what I can do," says Nicholas.

text_7_right.eng: "I bet you can’t do this," says Jacob.

guidance_7_a.eng: Ask: “What are they doing? Can you do any of these moves? Show me!”

text_8.eng: "Here’s our picnic spot," says Dad.

guidance_8_a.eng: Describe the picture by saying, “Wow, mom and dad have found a beautiful picnic spot next to the river.” Ask: “How do you think everyone is going to feel about it?”

text_9.eng: "Race you to the water!" says Jacob.

guidance_9_a.eng: Ask: “What are they doing? Wheeee, they are jumping into the water! Who is making the biggest splash? Would you also jump in? Why or why not?”

text_10.eng: "Come and eat, boys and girls," says Mom.

guidance_10_a.eng: Ask: “What is everyone eating? What would you choose to eat? Is everyone eating food? What about the baby? And what about the donkey?”

text_11.eng: "Time to go home," says Mom. "Say goodbye to Jacob."

guidance_11_a.eng:
Say: “Now it is time to go home (mimic waving and saying goodbye). Can you also wave?”

Ask: “Now tell me, how do you feel when you have to leave your friends after playing together? Why do you feel that way?”

guidance_12_a.eng:
Help your child learn new words. Say: Look, the sky is dark and the stars are out, it is time to sleep.” Then say: What is on the roof of their house? Where is the pumpkin? And where are the bricks?”

“Would you enjoy a picnic? Let’s have our lunch outside under the tree today and pretend to have our own picnic!”

rows.author: Sindeka Mandoyi
rows.title: A trip to the tap

description.eng: Oluhle fetches water at the tap every day. She gets to carry her favourite pink bucket. But one day it gets lost …

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: Oluhle wakes up early. She is excited to get water. “Come Mama, we have to be first today,” she calls.

text_2_left.eng: On the way they meet Nathi and Unathi. They are going to the tap with their mother.

text_3_left.eng: Oluhle and her friends play while the grown-ups get water. “Oluhle, your bucket is full,” says Mama.

text_4_left.eng: At home, Oluhle takes a bath. Mama goes to work and Oluhle stays with Makhulu.

text_5_left.eng: In the afternoon Makhulu starts to make supper. She needs more water. She calls Oluhle so they can go to the tap.

text_6_left.eng: “Makhulu, I can’t find my bucket. I searched everywhere,” says Oluhle. Makhulu helps her look, but the bucket is nowhere to be found.

text_7_left.eng: Makhulu thinks of a plan. She gets a 2-litre bottle from the cupboard and fetches paints and paint brushes.

text_8_left.eng: Makhulu makes a bucket from the water bottle. She paints it pink. “Here’s a recycled bucket, Oluhle!”

text_9_left.eng: “Thank you, Makhulu,” says Oluhle. She is excited to go to the tap with her new recycled bucket.

text_10_left.eng: The next day Unathi and Nathi bring two bottles to Makhulu. “Makhulu, could you please make recycled buckets for us?”

text_11_left.eng: Makhulu paints their buckets yellow and blue, their favourite colours. Nathi and Unathi are happy. Oluhle is happy too.

text_12_left.eng: The friends can’t wait to show off with their new buckets. “Can we go to the tap now?” they ask.

rows.author: Tshepo Letsapa
rows.title: Fifi and Teddy

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover. Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: Fifi has a brown teddy bear that she loves very much. But where is Teddy?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1.eng: Fifi has loved Teddy since she was a baby.

guidance_1_a.eng: Say: “Look, there is a girl and a teddy.” Ask: “Who do you think this teddy belongs to?”

text_2.eng: Fifi eats with Teddy. Fifi plays with Teddy.

guidance_2_a.eng: Point at the picture and Ask: “What do you think the girl and teddy are doing?” Point to the picture of the girl on the swing and ask again: “How do you think she is feeling? Why do you say that?”

text_3.eng: Fifi takes Teddy wherever she goes. And they curl up together every night.

guidance_3_a.eng: Ask: “Who is sitting at the back of the car? Where do you think they might be going? Where is teddy sleeping? Do you sleep with anything in your bed?”

text_4.eng: Fifi knows she cannot take Teddy to school. So every morning she leaves Teddy on her bed.

guidance_4_a.eng: Say: “Oh no! Where is the girl? Teddy is alone. How do you think Teddy feels?”

text_5.eng: One day, when she comes back from school, Teddy is not there!

guidance_5_a.eng:
Say: “Look who's back. Oh no, Teddy is not there.” Mimic for your child a surprised expression.

Ask: “how would you feel if your special toy went missing?”

guidance_6_a.eng: Ask: “What is the girl looking for? Where is she looking? Where do you think teddy might have gone?”

guidance_7_a.eng: Ask: “Where is she looking now? Where could teddy be hiding?” Mimic searching and feeling frustrated.

text_8.eng: “What’s wrong, Fifi?” asks Mom.

guidance_8_a.eng: Describe what is happening. Say: “The girl made a good plan. After searching on her own, she went to ask her mother for help. Remember that you can always ask for help if you need it.”

text_9.eng: Teddy is missing!

guidance_9_a.eng: Say: “Poor girl, she is crying because she can’t find her teddy. Do you remember yesterday when you were crying because you were frustrated with your little sister? What helped you to feel less frustrated?”

text_10.eng: “No, darling. Teddy just had a bath!”

guidance_10_a.eng: Say: “Jippy! Look, there is teddy! Why do you think teddy is hanging on the washing line?”

text_11.eng: “There you are, Teddy!”

guidance_11_a.eng: Ask: “Why is the girl smiling and jumping up and down? What has made you feel this happy lately? Do you remember feeling happy when you scored a goal when we were playing soccer together?”

guidance_12_a.eng: Ask: Now tell me, what did you think about this story? What did you learn?”

rows.author: Tania Kliphuis
rows.title: How do you want your eggs?

title.eng: How do you want your eggs?

description.eng: Boiled, scrambled or fried? How does Luzuko want his eggs?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_2.eng: It’s time for breakfast.

text_3_left.eng: How do you want your eggs?

text_4_left.eng: Do you want boiled eggs, Luzuko?

text_6_left.eng: Do you want scrambled eggs, Luzuko?

text_8_right.eng: Do you want fried eggs, Luzuko?

text_10_left.eng: Well? How do you want your eggs, Luzuko?

text_12_left.eng: Today, I just want a bowl of porridge.

rows.author: Siphosethu Zantsi
rows.title: Lebo and Gogo's Tea Party

description.eng: Lebo is excited to have a day of adventure with Gogo. When Gogo hurts herself, she can’t do anything that Lebo wants to do. What can Gogo and Lebo do to have fun together?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: Lebo is at Gogo’s farm. She is bored with chasing the animals. "Now you chase me, Gogo!" Lebo shouts as she races past. "Slow down, Lebo," Gogo says, hurrying to catch up.

text_2_left.eng: Gogo trips over a rock while chasing Lebo. "Ouch!" she screams. Gogo has hurt her ankle.

text_3_right.eng: She comes back from the doctor with a special boot and crutches. "Gogo, come back to the city with us so that we can take care of you," says Lebo’s mom. "I won’t leave my farm. I will manage on my own," Gogo replies, stubbornly.

text_4_left.eng: "Gogo, you must come. We will have so much fun!" Lebo says, excitedly.

text_5.eng: During the drive, Lebo bounces on her seat. She thinks of all the wild adventures she and Gogo will have in the city.

text_6_left.eng: When they arrive at the house, Gogo rests on the sofa.

text_7_left.eng: Lebo dashes into the lounge. "Gogo, Gogo, I know what we can do today! We can go to the mall. There are lots of shops with nice toys and ice cream!" "I’m afraid I can’t. The mall is too big, and I will get so tired."

text_8_left.eng: "Gogo, Gogo, I know what we can do today! We can go to the park!" "I’m afraid that won’t work. The dogs in the park will run around and could make me fall again."

text_9_left.eng: A second later, Lebo’s eyes are wide with excitement. "Gogo, Gogo, I know what else we can do today. Let’s go to the beach." "I’m sorry, Lebo. I’m afraid my crutches will sink into the soft sand."

text_10_left.eng: Lebo is quiet while Gogo knits. Suddenly she has an idea!

text_11_left.eng: "Gogo, Gogo, I know what we can do today! Let’s have a tea party. Gogo, you can sit here. I will bring everything to you because you are hurt."

rows.author: Mathapelo Mabaso
rows.title: Lesedi’s Sandbox

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: Lesedi dreams of going to the beach. He wants to feel the sand between his toes and build a sandcastle. So his parents come up with a plan…

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: It’s the holidays and I’d love to go to the beach, but we have never been. I wonder what it feels like to play in the sea sand.

guidance_1_a.eng: Describe what you see, or ask your child to tell you what they see. Ask: where do you think this boy wants to go?

text_2_right.eng: Surprise! "Look what we made you. A sandbox," exclaims Lesedi’s dad. Dad says he used some of his old tyres. Mom painted them with all my favourite colours: blue, red and yellow.

guidance_2_a.eng: Point to boy and ask: “How do you think he is feeling? What do you think he is going to do next?”

text_3_left.eng: I can’t wait to get inside. I climb into my sandbox and my feet feel so warm and squishy.

guidance_3_a.eng: Mimic actions from the pictures or story. Pretend to put your feet in the sand and wiggle your toes.

text_4_left.eng: Look! I’m at the beach. That looks like a good spot to spread my blanket. I set up my umbrella, but the wind blows it away.

guidance_4_a.eng: Mimic the sound of the wind and the umbrella blowing away. Demonstrate surprise and ask your child how they would feel if that happened to them.

text_5_left.eng: The ocean makes a roaring sound. I run on the beach, daring the waves to catch me as I make footprints in the sand.

guidance_5_a.eng: Mimic the sound of the ocean or the movement of the waves. Point to the footprints in the sand and explain what this is.

text_6_left.eng: Using my bucket and spade, I dig for shells. They come in many shapes and sizes.

guidance_6_a.eng: Ask your child: How many shells can you see? What colours are they? Are they all the same shape? Which shells are big? Which shells are small?

text_7_right.eng: Let me build a sandcastle. Wow, that’s huge!

guidance_7_a.eng: Describe the picture to your child or ask them what they see. Ask: do you like to play in the sand? Why or why not?

text_8_left.eng: It’s lunchtime! Maybe I should have a strawberry jam sandwich. Mmm, my favourite.

guidance_8_a.eng: Ask your child: where is he sitting? What is he eating?  What would you like to eat if you went to the beach?

text_9_right.eng: For dessert, Mom brings me some chocolate ice cream.

guidance_9_a.eng: Ask your child: what is she holding in her hand? Who is she giving it to?

text_10_left.eng: I lie on my blanket enjoying my ice cream and gaze at the sky turning pink.

guidance_10_a.eng: Use descriptive words and explanations to talk about the pictures. This helps your child learn new words. The big, round orange sun. The pink and blue sky with clouds. The boy relaxing on his blanket, enjoying his delicious ice cream.

text_11_right.eng: Lesedi’s mom and dad watch him, their eyes beaming with pleasure. "I’m so happy we could make his dream come true right here at home," Lesedi’s mom says.

guidance_11_a.eng: Talk about what the characters might be thinking or feeling. Ask: how does the boy feel? Why do you think he feels that way? Why are the parents smiling?

text_12_left.eng: Thank you, Mom and Dad. Today was the happiest day of my life!

guidance_12_a.eng: Ask your child: Is his clothes and hands dirty or clean? Why? What do you think he should do next?

guidance_13_a.eng: Ask your child: what did you think about the story? You could also pretend to have your own beach adventure with your child.

rows.author: Sope Martins
rows.title: Little Shoots

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover. Ask your child: What do you see? What is the woman pointing to?

description.eng: Layo can’t wait to grow. But just like the bamboo seeds he and grandma plant, it might take a little longer than he wants!

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

guidance_1_a.eng: Ask: what is the boy holding in his hand? What can you see in the photo?

text_2_left.eng: "I don’t know," replies Baba. "Soon," says Mama.

guidance_2_a.eng: Ask: how many people are sitting down? Who is standing? What is she carrying? Where is the cat? Can you see any other animals?

text_3_right.eng: Grandma takes Layo to the farm. "Let us plant some seeds."

guidance_3_a.eng: Ask: Where are they going? What are they looking at? How many orange animals can you see? Which birds are flying? Where is the mouse?

text_4_left.eng: In one field they plant corn, and in another, melon.

text_4_right.eng: "What are these?" asks Layo. "Bamboo seeds," replies Grandma.

guidance_4_a.eng: Use the pictures to help your child practice counting. You can ask your child to count, or count out loud for your child. Ask: How many yellow seeds are there? How many black seeds? How many seeds does she have in her left hand? And how many seeds does she have in her right hand? How many seeds are there altogether?

guidance_5_a.eng: Ask questions to help your child understand what is happening. Ask: What is the boy looking at? What can you see outside the window?

text_6_left.eng: "The corn and melon have grown well," says Grandma. "What about the bamboo?" asks Layo.

text_6_right.eng: "They will grow when they are ready."

guidance_6_a.eng: Describe and explain the pictures. Say: Look, the seeds they planted have grown. Some of the seeds have grown into tall corn plants. Other seeds have grown into big, round watermelons. What other plants can you see?

guidance_7_a.eng: Ask: Where is the boy standing? What is growing next to him? What is he looking at?

text_8_left.eng: "Everything grows in its own time," says Grandma.

guidance_8_a.eng: Ask: what looks different in this picture? What has changed?

guidance_9_a.eng: Make links between the pictures and your child’s world. Ask: What colour are their curtains? What colour curtains do we have at home? What do you see on their table? What do we have on our table?

guidance_10_a.eng: Ask: What are they looking at? How do you think they are feeling? Why?

guidance_11_a.eng: Describe and explain the pictures. Say: Look, the three boys from the photo are now older.

text_12.eng: “You have grown well.”

guidance_12_a.eng: Ask: what looks different in this picture? What has changed?

guidance_13_a.eng: Reflect on the story with your child. Ask: What happened in this story? What was the story about? What did you think of the story?

rows.guidance_13_a: Reflect on the story with your child. Ask: What happened in this story? What was the story about? What did you think of the story?

rows.author: Sue Boucher
rows.title: Look out, Luthando!

description.eng: Luthando is very good at listening and very good at smelling, but he’s not so good at looking where he is going. He walks into puddles and bumps his head. What could be the problem?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: "Listen!" says Luthando. "What do you hear?" asks Sonto. "Saturday." "What does Saturday sound like?" "It’s quieter than Friday," says Luthando. "Everyone’s still sleeping."

text_2_left.eng: "I must fix Gogo’s gate today," Daddy says.

text_2_right.eng: "An ice cream for anyone who helps me carry the shopping home," Mama says. "We’ll help you, Mama," say the children.

text_3_left.eng: "Look out, Luthando!" "Hawu!" "You’re so funny," Sonto laughs.

text_4_right.eng: "There’s no motorbike," says Sonto, looking all around.

text_5_left.eng: A motorbike zooms past. "You’re very good at hearing, Luthando."

text_6_left.eng: "Look out, Luthando!" "Hawu!" says Luthando as he steps into a puddle.

text_6_right.eng: "Look how wet you are," says Mama.

text_7_left.eng: "Daddy’s home." "How do you know, Luthando?" asks Sonto.

text_7_right.eng: "I can smell his cooking," says Luthando sniffing the air. "You’re also good at smelling," Mama says.

text_8_left.eng: "Look out, Luthando!" "Ouch!" "Watch where you’re walking," Mama says. "Luthando’s not so good at looking," says Sonto.

text_9_left.eng: "What do you see, Luthando?" asks the friendly woman. Luthando squeezes his eyes together. He sees black squiggles on the wall.

text_9_right.eng: He looks through a pair of glasses. "I see letters," he says. "Excellent!"

text_10_left.eng: "Look, Gogo!" "You have glasses," says Gogo, clapping her hands. "How wonderful. Tell me what you see."

text_10_right.eng: "I see bugs and ants and spiders and bees. I see EVERYTHING now."

text_11_left.eng: "Gogo, your face has cracks," says Luthando, touching Gogo’s face. "Hayi...Luthando! Those aren’t cracks. They’re lines on my face from getting old and laughing at all the funny things you say."

text_12.eng: "Don’t..."

text_12_left.eng: "Look, a puddle!" says Luthando. Too late!

rows.author: Jen Thorpe
rows.title: My inside weather

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: Sometimes our feelings are hard to talk about, but everyone knows how to talk about the weather.

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: It’s easy to talk about the weather outside, even if it changes all the time.

guidance_1_a.eng: Describe the picture and say, “Look up! The sun is out and the sky is mostly blue, with just a few fluffy grey things floating around. That means it's going to be a super fun day to play outside!”

text_2_left.eng: But it’s hard to talk about the weather inside me. Sometimes it feels like people don’t understand.

guidance_2_a.eng:
Point at the thought bubbles around the girl and say, “Look at this girl, could she be thinking about the weather? 


Ask, “Point at the thought that shows rain, point at the one that shows cloudy weather and point at the one that shows sunny weather. Now tell me, which one is your favourite? Why or why not?”

text_3_left.eng: Do you feel like that too?

guidance_3_a.eng: Say, “Now look at the mother and the girl having a conversation, maybe they are discussing the weather.”

text_4_left.eng: Some days my mind is full of sunshine and rainbows. I feel like I can do anything.

guidance_4_a.eng:
Point at the picture and say, “Let’s have a look at the girl’s thought bubble again.’

Ask, “What are the two things in her thought bubble that she is maybe thinking about? What colors are they?”

text_5_left.eng: On other days my head is full of fog and clouds. It’s hard to listen to what people are saying or to remember things.

guidance_5_a.eng: Point at the girl and say, “Let's look at the girl again, It looks like she is now thinking about the clouds.”

text_6_left.eng: I sometimes wake up feeling like it’s windy and wild in my head. I feel tired and grumpy.

guidance_6_a.eng:
Say, “Oh no! She seems really frustrated. Perhaps the weather is really confusing her.”

Ask, “Now tell me, how do you act when you are frustrated or confused.”

text_7_left.eng: And sometimes it feels like it’s raining inside me. It can be a drizzle making me feel sad, or a storm making me feel angry.

guidance_7_a.eng: Help the child learn new words by pointing and naming different things and say, “Let's learn new words! See this light rain? We call it "drizzling." Can you say "drizzling"? Now, look at that big, loud rain with thunder and lightning! That's a "storm." Can you say "storm"? Drizzling is soft rain, and a storm is big and loud rain!

text_8_left.eng: Sometimes the weather inside me doesn’t match the weather outside.

guidance_8_a.eng: Point at the picture and say, “Let's look at the dress the girl is wearing, what color is the dress? What color are the dots on the dress? How many dots on the dress can you see?

text_9_left.eng: Sometimes my inside weather doesn’t match how I want to feel or how I think I should feel.

guidance_9_a.eng: Point at the picture and ask again, “Let's peek outside! What do you see? Look at the big, bright sun! What color is it? Now, count the pretty flowers outside. One, two, three... How many flowers are there? What colors are the flowers? Are they yellow? Maybe some purple? And what about the green stuff all over the ground? That's the grass! What color is the grass?”

text_10_left.eng: Is that okay? Yes, of course it is.

guidance_10_a.eng:
Say, “Look at the mother and the girl looking at each other as they engage in a conversation.”

Ask, “Now tell me, how many eyes does the girl and the mother have? `how many eyes do you have? How many hands does the mother have? How many hands do you have?

text_11_left.eng: The best thing to do when we feel like our inside weather is strange is to tell someone we love, and talk about it.

guidance_11_a.eng: Point at the couch and say, “Okay, now let's count legs! First, look at this couch. Count how many legs it has. One, two, maybe more? How many? Now, let's count your legs! How many legs do you have? Are the number of legs the same on the couch and on you?

text_12_left.eng: They’ve got inside weather too, and they’ll understand.

guidance_12_a.eng: Ask, “What are your thoughts about this story? Do you like it? Why or why not?

rows.author: Refiloe Moahloli
rows.title: The Things That Really Matter

guidance_cover.eng: Bring your child’s attention to the book’s cover. Ask: What are they doing? What do you think this story could be about?

description.eng: What are the most important things to take with you on a trip? Join Zuki, Tando, Mama and Papa on their eventful journey to find out.

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_right.eng: We are going on a trip. I ask Mama what to pack. She says, "The things that really matter."

guidance_1_a.eng: Describe what you see, or ask your child to tell you what they see. Ask: what are they doing? Where do you think they could be going?

text_2.eng: We stop at the windmill for breakfast. The jungle gym is so much fun. I forget my toy.

guidance_2_a.eng: Discuss what the characters are doing. Ask: what are the children doing? Who is waving? Why are they waving?

text_3_right.eng: I am sad in the car, but Tando is happy. "Hooray! Now you can play with me!" he says.

guidance_3_a.eng: Use descriptive words to talk about the pictures. Say: Look, they are wearing their seatbelts because they are in the car. Why do you think they are wearing seatbelts?

text_4_left.eng: We stop at a farm to see some animals. Tando is searching so hard for a springbok, a monkey gets away with his headphones.

guidance_4_a.eng: Ask your child to count the animals, or count them for your child. Ask questions to help your child understand what is happening. Ask: what is the monkey doing? Does the boy know what is happening?

text_5_right.eng: He is sad in the car, but I am happy. "Hooray! Now you can sing with me!" I say.

guidance_5_a.eng: Talk about what the characters might be thinking or feeling. Ask: how does the boy feel? Why do you think he feels that way?

text_6_left.eng: We stop at a roaring waterfall. We are so excited, we are pushing and pulling.

text_6_right.eng: Papa falls in the water, and so does his map.

guidance_6_a.eng: Ask: what are they looking at? Say: oh no! Someone fell over! You can mimic the actions, like taking a picture, or falling down.

text_7_right.eng: He is sad in the car, but Mama is happy. "Hooray! Now I can help you find our way!" she says.

guidance_7_a.eng: Ask: how does the father feel? Why do you think he feels that way? Why is he wet?

text_8_left.eng: We stop at the roadside vendor to buy some mielies.

text_8_right.eng: Mama bends over to pick the best ones, and her glasses fall and  break.

guidance_8_a.eng: Ask: Why did they get out of the car? What is the man in the hat selling? What happened to the women’s glasses? Why did that happen?

text_9_right.eng: Mama is sad in the car, but Papa is happy. "Hooray! Now we can find our way together!" Papa says.

guidance_9_a.eng: Ask: how many people are in the car? How many are sitting at the front? And how many are sitting at the back?

text_10_left.eng: We stop on an ancient hill to get a view of the valley. Papa is making silly jokes for us to smile for the picture, but...

guidance_10_a.eng: To help your child understand, explain what is happening. Say: Look, there is smoke coming out of the car. Do you think there might be something wrong with the car?

text_11_right.eng: When we get back to the car, it won’t start. Everyone stops laughing. "Don’t worry..." says Mama. "We can still have a good time. We are the things that really matter."

guidance_11_a.eng: Demonstrate the emotions from the story with your voice and face. Say: Look, they are all feeling sad. Why do you think they are feeling that way?

text_12_right.eng: And so, we do have a good time. By playing and singing and finding our way together, while enjoying the best mielies.

guidance_12_a.eng: Ask: Where are they sitting? What are they doing? How do you think they are feeling now?

guidance_13_a.eng: Reflect on the story with your child. Ask: What did you think about the story? How would you feel if you were in the story? What would you have done?

rows.author: Clea Mallinson
rows.title: To The Top!

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover. Ask your child: What do you see? Where do you think they might be going?

description.eng: Climb the mountain with us! Look out for many tiny creatures… and BIG views. If we help each other, we can get to the top!

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

guidance_1_a.eng: Describe the pictures, or ask your child to tell you what they see. Where are they? Where are they going? Respond with interest and enthusiasm.

guidance_2_a.eng: Describe and explain the pictures. “Look, here is a bird with a sharp beak and a long tail. The flowers are big and colourful. The father is holding a long stick that helps him to climb the mountain.

guidance_3_a.eng: Ask your child to point and name the animals. How many bees are flying? Where are the ants walking? Can we count them? Where is the frog hiding?

guidance_4_a.eng:
Ask your child: What is the father pointing at? What animal does the rock look like?
What is the girl doing?

guidance_5_a.eng: Ask your child: What are they doing? Why are they stopping? What can you see around them?

guidance_6_a.eng:
Discuss what the characters are doing. 
Why are they sitting down? What are they eating? What would you like to eat if you were there?

guidance_7_a.eng: Mimic the sound of the wind and the hat blowing away. Ask: What happened to her hat? Why did that happen?

guidance_8_a.eng: Ask: Who found the hat? How does the girl feel now that her hat has been found?

guidance_9_a.eng: Ask: What is the girl feeling? Why is she feeling that way? What can her father do to help?

guidance_10_a.eng: Ask your child: Why is she sitting on her father’s shoulders? How is she feeling now?

guidance_11_a.eng: Ask your child: Where is the frog sitting? What is the bird doing? Who is sitting at the top of the hill?

guidance_12_a.eng: Ask: why are they sitting down? What are they looking at? How would you feel after climbing such a big mountain?

guidance_13_a.eng: Act out events from the book at a later stage. Go for a walk with your child and see what animals and birds you can spot as you walk. Or, collect different hats around your house and make a game out of hiding them and trying to find them.

rows.author: Mohale Mashigo
rows.title: Where is Lulu?

description.eng: Where is Lulu and why is she hiding?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_2_left.eng: "Lulu! It’s time to go," calls Ma.

text_3.eng: Where is Lulu? Is she under the sofa? Is she behind the curtain?

text_4.eng: Where is Lulu? Is she next to the stove? Is she in the cupboard?

text_5_left.eng: "Lulu! It’s time to go. Where are you?" calls Ma.

text_6_left.eng: "There you are!" "I don’t want to gooo!"

text_7_left.eng: "We have to go," says Ma. "But I really like this one!"

text_10.eng: "And this one." "And this one." "And this one."

text_11_left.eng: "See? You return books and borrow more." "YAY!"

rows.text_3: Where is Lulu? Is she under the sofa? Is she behind the curtain?
rows.text_4: Where is Lulu? Is she next to the stove? Is she in the cupboard?
rows.text_7_left: "We have to go," says Ma. "But I really like this one!"
rows.text_11_left: "See? You return books and borrow more." "YAY!"

rows.author: Laurie Janey
rows.title:
Ouma’s
Amazing Flowers

description.eng: Ouma has amazing flowers! Robyn wants to pick them all …

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: Ouma has a window box full of amazing flowers. Robyn wants to pick them all!

text_2_right.eng: Please don’t pick the flowers, Robyn! Ouma loves to see them when she opens her curtains.

text_3_left.eng: Butterflies dance around the petals. It’s so lovely to have these visitors.

text_4_right.eng: The bees use the flowers to make delicious honey.

text_5_left.eng: The flowers bring joy to everyone who walks past Ouma’s house.

text_6_right.eng: The neighbour likes to smell them when he visits for tea.

text_7_left.eng: Sometimes, sunbirds drink the sweet nectar from the flowers.

text_8_right.eng: Look, a tiny beetle! It shines in the sun. And there’s a fat caterpillar!

text_9_left.eng: Please don’t pick Ouma’s flowers, Robyn! They won’t stay fresh very long.

text_10_right.eng: "I won’t pick them, Ouma," says Robyn, even though she really wants to. She feels a little bit sad!

text_11_left.eng: Ouma doesn’t want Robyn to be sad. "Okay, Robyn," says Ouma. "You can pick your favourite flower."

text_12_right.eng: "And I have an idea ... Let’s plant more flowers together!"

rows.author: Edem Torkornoo
rows.title: Baby’s First Family Photo

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover. Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: Baby’s family is excited about their first family photo. What will Mama, Papa, Big Sister, Baby and Gogo wear?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: Whose bright orange wrapper is this? It is Mama’s.

guidance_1_a.eng: Ask your child questions about the pictures. Ask: What is she wearing on her head? What colour is it?

text_2_left.eng: Whose blue shirt is this? It is Papa's.

guidance_2_a.eng: Describe the pictures to your child. Say: Look, he is wearing a shirt with blue patterns and a blue tie. His glasses are also blue.

text_3_left.eng: Whose yellow head wrap is this? It is Gogo's.

guidance_3_a.eng: Ask: Who can you see? What is she wearing? Why do you think she is wearing glasses? Do you know someone who wears glasses?

text_4_left.eng: Whose pretty red dress is this? It is Big Sister’s.

guidance_4_a.eng: Describe the pictures to help your child learn words. Say: Look, she has tied her hair with big green and red bows. The patterns on the bows are the same pattern as her dress.

text_5_left.eng: Whose green and yellow flowery dress is this? It is mine!

guidance_5_a.eng: Make links between the pictures and your child’s world. Ask: What is she wearing? What are you wearing today? What colours are your clothes today? And what colours are my clothes?

text_6_left.eng: "I love my orange wrapper." Mama twirls.

guidance_6_a.eng: Ask: What is she doing? Why do you think she is doing that?

text_7_left.eng: "I love my blue shirt." Papa bows.

guidance_7_a.eng: Ask: What is he doing? Let’s try to do the same move as him.

text_8_left.eng: "I love my yellow head wrap." Gogo jiggles.

guidance_8_a.eng: Use the pictures to teach your child about different shapes. Say: How many circles or round shapes can you see? What colours are they? Look, her clothes are covered in a yellow diamond pattern.

text_9_left.eng: "I love my pretty red dress." Big Sister jumps up and down.

guidance_9_a.eng: Ask: What colours are on her dress? What colour shoes is she wearing? What is she doing?

text_10_left.eng: "I love my green flowery dress." I clap my hands.

guidance_10_a.eng: Mimic actions from the story, like clapping hands. Ask: why do you think she is clapping her hands? How is she feeling?

guidance_11_a.eng: Ask: What are they going to do now? Why do you say that? How many people are there?

guidance_12_a.eng: Make links between the pictures and your child’s world. Do we have a family photo? Who is in it? Or, should we take a family photo later when we are all together? What do you want to do for our family photo?

rows.author: Edna Gicovi
rows.title: Brave Bora

description.eng: Going to the doctor can be scary! Can Bora overcome his fears, with a little help from Baba and Jojo?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_right.eng: Bora is sitting at the clinic with Baba. Jojo, his stuffed monkey, came too. Jojo is sleeping in Bora’s bag.

text_2_right.eng: "I don’t like needles. They hurt!" says Bora.

text_3_right.eng: "An injection helps make you healthy. It’s okay to be scared, Bora. Baba will be right here with you. And Jojo too."

text_4_left.eng: "Bora Baraka!" a loud voice calls. "Let’s go Bora, " says Baba. "It’s your turn."

text_5_left.eng: "Let’s come back tomorrow Baba!" says Bora.

text_6_left.eng: "Remember what Baba said you will get for being brave enough to get your injection?" asks Baba. "A red  lollipop! Okay, I’m coming," says Bora.

text_7.eng: The doctor smiles at Bora. "Is this your  monkey? Can we examine him too?" she asks.

text_7_left.eng: Bora looks at Baba, then at Jojo, and nods.

text_8_right.eng: "Now, it’s your turn," she says. "Will you help me give your monkey a small injection so he feels better?" asks the doctor.

text_9_right.eng: "TOOP!" says the doctor as she gives Jojo the monkey an injection.

text_10_right.eng: "Now, it’s your turn. Is that a superhero on your T-shirt?" she asks.

text_11_left.eng: "TOOP!" She says as she gives Bora the injection.

text_12_right.eng: "Ouch!" shouts Bora. "Hey, that wasn’t so bad!"

text_13_right.eng: "I know it stings a little, but we’re done and you have been very brave!" says the doctor.

text_14.eng: "One red lollipop for our brave Bora!"

rows.author: Lauren Beukes
rows.title: And Also!

description.eng: Thabo’s make-believe world has no room for his little sister, Keitu. But she has other ideas!

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1.eng: Thabo pretends that his bed is a raft on the sea!

text_2_left.eng: His little sister Keitu says, "Yes ! And also! There are sharks."

text_3_left.eng: Thabo pretends that their taxi is a spaceship!

text_4_left.eng: His little sister Keitu says, "Yes! And also! Watch out for shooting stars!"

text_5_left.eng: Thabo pretends the playground is a jungle!

text_6_left.eng: His little sister Keitu says, "Yes! And also! We are lions."

text_7_left.eng: "Oh!" says Thabo, "Wait! Wow! Yes! That’s a great idea!"

text_8_left.eng: Thabo pretends to be a lion! Keitu also pretends to be a lion!

text_9_left.eng: Thabo pretends the other kids are a river of crocodiles!

text_9_right.eng: Keitu says, "Yes! And also! We can jump on this log to float away."

text_10_left.eng: "Yes! And also!" Thabo says, "We can slide down the rainbow!"

text_10_right.eng: Keitu says, "Yes! And also! Watch out for the dinosaurs!"

text_12_left.eng: Thabo says, "I had the best day playing pretend with you."

text_12_right.eng: Keitu says, "And also! We should play again tomorrow!"

rows.author: Vinayak Varma
rows.title: Angry Akku

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: Akku is having an awful day and it’s making her very, VERY angry. Read this book to find out how Akku's anger melts away, and get ideas on what to do when YOU are very, VERY angry.

text_1.eng: When the last school bell rang, all the children laughed and screamed with joy. All, except Akku. Akku was ANGRY!

guidance_1_a.eng: Describe and point at the children in the picture and say, “Hmmm.. It looks like all the children are happy and dancing except for this one. She looks really sad, I wonder what could be wrong.”

text_2_left.eng: "Akku! Akku! Look at the pretty sunflowers!" said Appa, as they rode through a field. "GRRMPH! They’re TOO YELLOW! They’re making my eyes hurt!" said Akku.

guidance_2_a.eng:
Help the child to learn new words by pointing at different items in the picture and say, “Look at this picture. I'm going to point to things, and you say the words after me, okay?”
Then say, "These are sunflowers. Can you say 'sunflowers'? That is a bicycle. Can you say 'bicycle'? Those are palm trees. Can you say 'palm trees'? And that is a huge tree trunk. Can you say 'tree trunk'?"

text_3.eng: "Akku! Akku! Look! Look at all the monkeys!" said Appa, pointing at the roof of their house. "CHEEE!" said Akku. "SHOOO! Go AWAY!  SHOOO!"

guidance_3_a.eng: Point in the picture and say, “What is that on the roof? Is that what I think it is?”

guidance_4_a.eng:
Say, “Oooh, are those monkeys on the roof?”

Ask, “How many monkeys do you see? How many monkeys have tails? How many monkeys have big grey beards?

text_5.eng: "Here, drink some buttermilk," said Appa. "It’ll cool you  down." "HRRRM!" said Akku. "I DON’T WANT ANY!" "Try a sip, at least?" "OKAY! FINE!" said Akku, and tried a sip. It wasn’t all that bad. She had another sip. And another. In no time, the glass was empty.

guidance_5_a.eng:
Say, “Imagine you're this girl, and there are monkeys around! Would you feel a little bit scared? Maybe!”
Ask, “If you felt scared, what could you do to feel better? Could you take a deep breath? Maybe close your eyes for a second? Or maybe you'd want to hold someone's hand? What do you think would help you feel calm?”

text_6_left.eng: "Would you like a vada?" asked Appa. "FFEHH!" said Akku. "Just one little bite?" "Okay, FINE!" said Akku, and took a bite. It was quite good. She took another bite. And another. In no time, the plate was empty.

guidance_6_a.eng: Say, “Now look at the girl again. It looks like the father gave her something nice to eat. Perhaps to get her smile, but still, she doesn't look happy. I wonder what could have upset her.”

text_7_left.eng: "Good girl," said Appa. "Now will you tell me why you’re so angry?" "NO!" said Akku. "Was it something I did?" "NO!" "Was it something Amma did?" "NO!" "Did something bad happen in school today?" "MAYBE!" "Oho."

guidance_7_a.eng: Ask, “If you were this girl, and something had upset you, how would you react?”

text_8.eng: "Would you like to draw it?" asked Appa. "Here’s a nice sheet of paper and some crayons." "Okay, FINE!" said Akku.

guidance_8_a.eng: Ask, “Now tell me, how many crayons do you see in this picture? How many papers do you see? What do you think the girl is going to do with the paper and crayons?

text_9.eng: Akku drew a brick... "This is the STUPID BRICK that I tripped over this morning," said Akku. "You’re right. That IS a VERY STUPID brick!" said Appa.

guidance_9_a.eng: Ask, “What color is the girl using to draw on a paper? What shape is the drawing? Can you guess what he is drawing?

text_10_left.eng: And Akku drew a boy... "This is Bikku, a VERY BAD BOY! He laughed when I fell down!" said Akku. "You’re right," said Appa. "He shouldn’t have laughed at you."

guidance_10_a.eng: Say, “Hmmm! there is another drawing, i wonder who this could be. Who do you think this is?

text_11_left.eng: And Akku drew an idli... "This is my idli," said Akku. "It fell out of my lunch box when I tripped over the STUPID BRICK!"

guidance_11_a.eng: Point at the picture and say, “That looks like something to eat. What color is it? What shape is it? How many dots are inside the drawing?”

text_12.eng: And Akku drew a crow... "This is the VERY BAD CROW that flew off with my idli," said Akku. "The crow must have been very hungry," said Appa.

guidance_12_a.eng:
Point at the picture making a sad sound and say, “Oh no, a bird flew away with a biscuit, what will the girl eat?”

Ask, “Now show me how a bird flies. Do you think you can catch it?”

text_13_left.eng: And Akku drew her teacher... "This is my teacher, Amala Miss," said Akku. "She helped me up when I fell down. And then she hugged me." "That’s nice of her," said Appa "And then she pinched my cheeks. I DON’T LIKE IT when my cheeks are pinched." "Oho! That must have HURT, no?" "A little bit. But I’m okay now." "That’s good."

guidance_13_a.eng:
Point at the picture and say, “There is another drawing.” 

Connect what is in the book with the child’s experience by pointing at the hand in the picture and saying, “How many fingers can you see? How many fingers do you have? What color is the hand? What color is your hand?”

text_14.eng: "See how well you draw, Akku?" said Appa. "You’re a real artist! Will you draw something for Amma too?" "OH-kay!" said Akku, and started drawing some more. "This is a little white mouse... and this is a boat... and this is a coconut tree..."

guidance_14_a.eng: Point at the feet and say, “Now look at the fathers feet. How many feet does he have? How many feet do you have? How many toes does he have? How many toes do you have?

text_15.eng: "And this is a sun flower... and this is your cycle, Appa... and this is a dog... and this is a frog..." In no time, Akku had forgotten all about the STUPID BRICK that made her trip and fall. And about the BAD BOY who laughed at her. And about the IDLI- STEALING CROW. And Akku even forgot about being ANGRY.

guidance_15_a.eng:
Reflect on the girl's drawings and say, “Wow, she made so many pictures.”

Ask, “How do you think she feels now after drawing all of them? Maybe drawing made her feel better and calmer?”
Then say, “When I feel mad, sometimes I go for a walk, or sing a little song, or read a fun book, or listen to music. These things help me feel calm again. Now it's your turn! When you feel angry, what do you do to feel calm? Tell me!”

text_16_left.eng:
10 Things to Do If You Feel ANGRY like Akku:
1. Laugh loudly and jump around with your arms in the air!
2. Slowly – very, very slowly – breathe in, and breathe out!
3. Drink some water! Or buttermilk! 
4. Eat a piece of fruit! Or a vada!
5. Tell a grown-up about how you’re feeling!
6. Write about how you’re feeling!
7. Draw it out! Paint it!
8. Play with a pile of clay!
9. Make up a song about your anger! Sing it aloud!
10. Dance like a monkey!

guidance_16_a.eng: Ask, “Can you tell me what you think about the story? Did you like it? Why or why not?”

rows.text_7_left: "Good girl," said Appa. "Now will you tell me why you’re so angry?" "NO!" said Akku. "Was it something I did?" "NO!" "Was it something Amma did?" "NO!" "Did something bad happen in school today?" "MAYBE!" "Oho."
rows.text_14: "See how well you draw, Akku?" said Appa. "You’re a real artist! Will you draw something for Amma too?" "OH-kay!" said Akku, and started drawing some more. "This is a little white mouse... and this is a boat... and this is a coconut tree..."
rows.text_15: "And this is a sun flower... and this is your cycle, Appa... and this is a dog... and this is a frog..." In no time, Akku had forgotten all about the STUPID BRICK that made her trip and fall. And about the BAD BOY who laughed at her. And about the IDLI- STEALING CROW. And Akku even forgot about being ANGRY.
rows.text_11_left: And Akku drew an idli... "This is my idli," said Akku. "It fell out of my lunch box when I tripped over the STUPID BRICK!"
rows.text_10_left: And Akku drew a boy... "This is Bikku, a VERY BAD BOY! He laughed when I fell down!" said Akku. "You’re right," said Appa. "He shouldn’t have laughed at you."
rows.guidance_13_a:
Point at the picture and say, “There is another drawing.” 

Connect what is in the book with the child’s experience by pointing at the hand in the picture and saying, “How many fingers can you see? How many fingers do you have? What color is the hand? What color is your hand?”
rows.text_13_left: And Akku drew her teacher... "This is my teacher, Amala Miss," said Akku. "She helped me up when I fell down. And then she hugged me." "That’s nice of her," said Appa "And then she pinched my cheeks. I DON’T LIKE IT when my cheeks are pinched." "Oho! That must have HURT, no?" "A little bit. But I’m okay now." "That’s good."
rows.guidance_14_a: Point at the feet and say, “Now look at the fathers feet. How many feet does he have? How many feet do you have? How many toes does he have? How many toes do you have?
rows.guidance_15_a:
Reflect on the girl's drawings and say, “Wow, she made so many pictures.”

Ask, “How do you think she feels now after drawing all of them? Maybe drawing made her feel better and calmer?”
Then say, “When I feel mad, sometimes I go for a walk, or sing a little song, or read a fun book, or listen to music. These things help me feel calm again. Now it's your turn! When you feel angry, what do you do to feel calm? Tell me!”
rows.text_16_left:
10 Things to Do If You Feel ANGRY like Akku:
1. Laugh loudly and jump around with your arms in the air!
2. Slowly – very, very slowly – breathe in, and breathe out!
3. Drink some water! Or buttermilk! 
4. Eat a piece of fruit! Or a vada!
5. Tell a grown-up about how you’re feeling!
6. Write about how you’re feeling!
7. Draw it out! Paint it!
8. Play with a pile of clay!
9. Make up a song about your anger! Sing it aloud!
10. Dance like a monkey!
rows.guidance_16_a: Ask, “Can you tell me what you think about the story? Did you like it? Why or why not?”

rows.author: Mulongo Bukheye and Ritah Katetemera
rows.title: Beloved Daughter

description.eng: Natabo has run away from her home! Do you know why?

licence.eng:
© African Storybook Initiative, 2016. Some rights reserved. Released
under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: This is Natabo. She has six brothers.

text_2.eng: Her parents give her a small pot. She loves it.

text_3.eng: One day her brothers break the pot.

text_4.eng: Natabo cannot find her pot. She cries and cries.

text_5.eng: Natabo runs away. She climbs a tall tree.

text_6.eng: Her parents find her. "Please come down," they ask.

text_7.eng: Her brothers sing, "Please come down."

text_8.eng: Natabo makes fun of their song.

text_9.eng: Then Natabo's friend comes. "Please come down," she sings.

text_10.eng: Natabo's friend sings until she comes down from the tree.

text_11.eng: The friends walk home together.

text_12.eng: Everyone celebrates that Natabo is home. Natabo gets a new pot!

rows.text_8: Natabo makes fun of their song.

rows.text_10: Natabo's friend sings until she comes down from the tree.
rows.text_11: The friends walk home together.
rows.text_12: Everyone celebrates that Natabo is home. Natabo gets a new pot!

rows.author: Mecelin Kakoro
rows.title: Big Blue Bus

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: Ebei and his mother are waiting for the big blue bus. Where is it?

licence.eng: © African Storybook Initiative, 2015. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: There was only one bus in Ebei's village. It was big and blue. It was very noisy.

guidance_1_a.eng:
Describe the picture and say, “Look, there is a big blue bus. It is the only bus in this village and people love it a lot.”

Ask, “Have you seen a bus in your village? If yes, what color is it?

text_2.eng: "Tomorrow we will go to town," said Ebei's mother. "We will buy your school uniform."

guidance_2_a.eng:
Say, "Look at this little cloud above their heads! That's a thought bubble. It shows what they might be saying to each other."
Ask, "Hmm... what do you think the mommy and her son are talking about in their thought bubbles?"

text_3.eng: Ebei was very excited. They would travel in the big blue bus. He could not sleep that night.

guidance_3_a.eng: Say, "Hmm... look at the boy. He's in bed, but he's not sleeping! He's still thinking about what his mommy said. Maybe she told him something super fun and exciting!"

text_4.eng: When his mother came to wake him, Ebei was already dressed.

guidance_4_a.eng: Say, “Wow, the boy is up and ready, I wonder where he might be going?”

text_5.eng: Ebei and his mother walked to the bus stop. They waited for the big blue bus. But the bus did not come.

guidance_5_a.eng:
Point at the picture and say, "Look at the boy and his mommy! What color is his shirt? What color are his pants? And what color are his shoes? Now, what color is Mommy's dress? What color are her shoes? And what color is her bag?”
Now point at the different items and ask, “Wow! Look at Mommy's dress! Can you count how many round circles are on it? Let's look at the trees! Can you count how many trees you can see in the picture?"
Then point to the road sign and say, "Hmm, that's a sign next to the boy. Can you guess what that sign might 
mean? Maybe it tells the bus to stop, or maybe it shows where to go!"

text_6.eng: Other people arrived at the bus stop. They complained because the bus was late. "Where is the bus?" they asked.

guidance_6_a.eng:
Say, "Look! More people came to the bus stop! They're all waiting for the bus. Hmm, maybe the bus is taking a little while. Oh no!" 
Ask, "Now, count all the people waiting for the bus. How many are there now? Have you ever ridden on a bus before?"

text_7.eng: Ebei was worried. "We will not be able to go to town," he thought. "I will not be able to get my uniform."

guidance_7_a.eng:
Say, "Look at the boy! He's waiting and waiting for the bus, and now he looks a little bit worried because it's getting late. Sometimes, when I'm worried, I get a little bit grumpy, like this..." (make a slightly worried or grumpy face).”
Ask, "Now, can you show me what your face looks like when you feel worried?"

text_8.eng: Some people gave up and went home. Ebei cried. He did not want to go. "We will wait a bit longer," said his mother.

guidance_8_a.eng:
Point at the picture and say, "Look! Some people are going away from the bus stop, but some are still waiting. Look at that boy over there... oh no! He looks like he is crying."
Ask, "How do you think that boy might be feeling? Why do you think he feels that way? What do you do when you feel sad?"

text_9.eng: Suddenly, they heard a noise. They saw dust in the air. The bus was coming!

guidance_9_a.eng:
Say, “Look! Everyone's looking that way! Their faces look like something’s happening! Maybe... is that the bus coming?"
Ask, "How do you think the people are feeling now? Are they excited? Maybe a little bit tired of waiting? What do you think?"

text_10.eng: But this bus was not blue. It was not big. It was red and small. The people did not want to get in this bus.

guidance_10_a.eng:
Act surprised and say, "Oops! That's not the blue bus! Okay, look closely at this bus.”
Ask, “What color is it?"

text_11.eng: "Get in! Get in!" shouted the driver. "We are very late today," he called.

guidance_11_a.eng: Help the child to learn new words. Point at the different items in the picture and say, “Okay, let's learn some new words! Look at this picture..."Say purse." (Wait for the child to repeat). Point to the briefcase, "Say briefcase." (Wait for the child to repeat). Point to the steering wheel, "Say steering wheel." (Wait for the child to repeat). Point to the rondavel, "Say rondavel." (Wait for the child to repeat)

text_12.eng: Ebei and his mother got in first. Soon everyone else got in the small red bus.

guidance_12_a.eng: Say, "Yay! Look! They're on the bus now! That means it's time to go! Hooray!"

text_13.eng: Ebei looked out the window. He saw more people at the bus stop.

guidance_13_a.eng:
Point at each of the different people in the picture and say, "Look at all these people! See their shirts? Everyone has a different color on their top!
Ask, "What color is this shirt? What about this one? Tell me the color of this top! And what color is this one right here?. 
Say, let's now look at what you are wearing. Then ask, “what color is your clothes? What about mine?”

text_14.eng: Even more people were running to catch the bus. But they were too late. The red bus was full. It left for town.

guidance_14_a.eng:
Say, "Uh oh! Look! The bus drove away, and some people missed it! They're running super fast to try and catch it! One person looks a little stuck.”
Ask, “What would you do if the bus left you behind? Would you run after it too? Can you show me how you would run?"

text_15.eng: "Where is the big blue bus?" asked Ebei's mother. "It broke down," replied the driver. "We are fixing it. It will come tomorrow."

guidance_15_a.eng: Say, "Look at the little cloud above their heads! That's like a thought bubble. I think the mother is asking the bus driver about the blue bus. Hmm... where could it have gone?"

text_16.eng: Ebei did not care about the colour of the bus. He did not care about the size. This bus was going to town!

guidance_16_a.eng: Ask the child to share their thoughts about the story and say, “Now tell me, what do you think about the story? What did you like the most about it?”
