rows.author: Ursula Nafula
rows.title: Decision

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: A village takes a decision together to change their lives for the better.

licence.eng: © African Storybook Initiative, 2015. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: My village had many problems. We made a long line to fetch water from one tap.

guidance_1_a.eng:
Describe the picture and say, “Look at this picture! Wow, lots and lots of people are waiting by the tap. They all want to get some water. Hmm, why are they all lined up like that? Maybe the water is coming out super slow?”

Ask, “What do you think?”

text_2.eng: We waited for food donated by others.

guidance_2_a.eng:
Point at the picture again and say, “Look at another queue, could the people be queuing for something else?”

Ask, “Let's look at the people who are wearing red, how many are they? How about those wearing green?”

Then say, “Now let's look at the clothes you are wearing, what colors are they?”

text_3.eng: We locked our houses early because of thieves.

guidance_3_a.eng:
Point at the picture and say, “Look at this picture! See the mother? She's closing the door with a key, click, click! And look, the window is also closed tight.”
Ask, “Hmm, why do you think mommy is locking the door? What do you think?

text_4.eng: Many children dropped out of school.

guidance_4_a.eng: Ask, “Can you tell me what is happening in this picture?”

text_5.eng: Young girls worked as maids in other villages.

guidance_5_a.eng:
Point at the picture and say, “Look, those are young girls. They are supposed to be in school but it looks like they are working as maids.”


Ask, “Do you think it's important for children to go to school? Why do you think so?

text_6.eng: Young boys roamed around the village while others worked on people's farms.

guidance_6_a.eng:
Point at the picture and say, “There seems to be many boys moving around the village. I wonder what they could be doing?”

Ask, “Now tell me, how many boys do you see in this picture?

text_7.eng: When the wind blew, waste paper hung on trees and fences.

guidance_7_a.eng:
Say, “Look at this picture! Whoa, the wind is super strong! See how everything is flying around? Even the papers are stuck on the tree!
Now, look at the man. The wind is taking his hat! How do you think he feels right now? Is he happy? Sad? Silly? Tell me what you think!

text_8.eng: People were cut by broken glass that was thrown carelessly.

guidance_8_a.eng: Say, “Oh no! Look at the boy's foot. Is that blood? Uh oh! What happened? There are so many broken things on the floor. Did he maybe step on them? It's a good idea to wear your shoes so your feet don't get hurt!

text_9.eng: Then one day, the tap dried up and our containers were empty.

guidance_9_a.eng:
Describe the characters emotions and say, “Okay, imagine everyone in the village is feeling a little bit sad and worried. The water tap is empty! That means no water to drink, no water to wash our hands, and maybe even no water for the plants.”
Ask, "Why do we need water? What do you use water for?" Tell me what you think!”

text_10.eng: My father walked from house to house asking people to attend a village meeting.

guidance_10_a.eng: Say, “Let's count the people in this picture! One, two, three... how many are there? Now, who is super tall? Can you point to the tallest person? And who is tiny? Point to the shortest person!”

text_11.eng: People gathered under a big tree and listened.

guidance_11_a.eng: Describe the picture and say, “Look! See all those people sitting under the big tree? They're talking about things that are making them sad in their village. Like, there's no water to drink, yucky trash all over the place, and broken stuff everywhere. Maybe they're talking together to try and make things better!”

text_12.eng: My father stood up and said, "We need to work together to solve our problems."

guidance_12_a.eng: Ask, “Do you think it's a good idea for them to talk and help each other fix these problems? Why do you think that?”

text_13.eng: Eight-year-old Juma, sitting on a tree trunk shouted, "I can help with cleaning up."

guidance_13_a.eng:
Say, “Wow! Even kids helped fix problems in their town! That's super cool, right?”

Ask, “Imagine if your friends had a problem, and you had a problem too. Would you help your friends think of ways to solve their problem?”

text_14.eng: One woman said, "The women can join me to grow food."

guidance_14_a.eng:
Point at the women in the picture and say, “Look at the ladies in the picture. See that bubbly cloud over their heads? That's their thinking bubble!”


Ask, “What do you think is going on inside their heads? What do you think they are saying to each other? Tell me your ideas!”

text_15.eng: Another man stood up and said, "The men will dig a well."

guidance_15_a.eng:
Point at the men in the picture, “Now let's look at these two men. See that bubbly cloud over their heads? That's their thinking bubble!”


Ask, “What do you think is going on inside their heads? What do you think they are saying to each other? Tell me your ideas!”

text_16.eng: We all shouted with one voice, "We must change our lives." From that day we worked together to solve our problems.

guidance_16_a.eng: Point at the people in the picture and say, “Look! Everyone is helping to fix their problem together. See all those happy faces? Even the little girl looks like she's dancing because they figured it out! Yay for them! They solved it! Isn't that super great?”

Ask, “What do you think is going on inside their heads? What do you think they are saying to each other? Tell me your ideas!”
rows.guidance_15_a:
Point at the men in the picture, “Now let's look at these two men. See that bubbly cloud over their heads? That's their thinking bubble!”


Ask, “What do you think is going on inside their heads? What do you think they are saying to each other? Tell me your ideas!”
rows.guidance_16_a: Point at the people in the picture and say, “Look! Everyone is helping to fix their problem together. See all those happy faces? Even the little girl looks like she's dancing because they figured it out! Yay for them! They solved it! Isn't that super great?”
rows.text_16: We all shouted with one voice, "We must change our lives." From that day we worked together to solve our problems.

rows.author: Mimi Werna
rows.title: Emotions Come and Go

description.eng: Look out for the emotions you feel and why!

licence.eng: © African Storybook Initiative, 2019. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: Ada is chuckling because she heard a funny story. She is smiling. What is Ada feeling?

text_2.eng: Gisa is feeling grumpy. He has a scowl on his face. Why is he irritated?

text_3.eng: Yuadoo is scared of the dark. Everyone feels fear sometimes. But Yuadoo can ask for help.

text_4.eng: Chidubem is worried about his school work. He can tell his teacher. He can ask for help.

text_5.eng: Lushan is playing around! It's okay to be silly sometimes.

text_6.eng: Eruro is feeling sad. It's okay to cry. Emotions come and go.

text_7.eng: Ayator is bursting with happiness. He is joyful. Emotions come and go.

text_8.eng: Hadiza is bored. She needs to find something to do.

text_9.eng: Ayo is angry. He is frustrated. Anger is a difficult feeling.

text_10.eng: Labake is excited. What's the cause of her excitement? Mother made her favourite food.

text_11.eng: Zege felt sleepy. He was very tired. "But wait, is 'sleepy' an emotion?" asks Efe.

text_12.eng: Efe is confused! Can you answer his question?

text_13.eng: Tega is feeling surprise and shock. He heard some gossip. Is it true?

text_14.eng: Yebo is sick. She feels miserable. She needs some medicine and rest to feel better.

text_15.eng: Sekyen is feeling content. She has finished her chores. Now she can play.

text_16.eng: Vandefan does not have chores today. He shows two thumbs up to Sekyen. "Good job, now let's play!" he says.

rows.author: Rehema Egbert
rows.title: Jasu Loves Football

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: Jasu loves football. She loves kicking the ball, hard! But she doesn't have her own ball. Jasu comes up with a plan.

licence.eng: © Room to Read, 2016. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: Jasu liked to play football.

guidance_1_a.eng: Say, “On ho, the girl lost her ball. How will she play football” Ask, “Do you play football? Why or why not?”

text_2.eng: But she lost her ball!

guidance_2_a.eng:
Say, “Look, a boy is playing with a ball, could that be the girl's ball?”

Ask, “How would you feel if you were the girl?”

text_3.eng: She looked for old socks, scrap paper, and thread.

guidance_3_a.eng:
Point at the following items and ask the child to name them. Point at each item and ask, “what is this?. 

Ask: “What do you think the girl is doing?”

text_4.eng: She made a ball.

guidance_4_a.eng:
Say, “Wow, is that a ball in a girl's hands? Could that mean she was making a ball?”

Ask, “Can tell me the colors you see on the ball.? What colors are the girls' shoes, dress and top. What colors are the mothers dress and top?”

text_5.eng: Jasu kicked her ball everywhere she went.

guidance_5_a.eng:
Say, “look, the girl is kicking her ball.” 

Ask, “do you know how to kick a ball? Can you show me how you kick a ball?”

text_6.eng: Jasu went to visit her grandpa. She kicked her ball into his mango tree. Some mangoes dropped.

guidance_6_a.eng:
Say, “Oh no, is that the girls ball on the tree?”

Ask, “How do you think the ball got there? How do you think the two mangoes on the ground got there?”

text_7.eng: Grandpa wasn’t happy. He told Jasu to be careful. Jasu apologized.

guidance_7_a.eng:
Say, “There is grandpa talking to the girl. What could he be saying to her? Could the ball have hit the mangoes?”

Ask, “What would you do if you were the girl and your ball caused grandpa’s mangoes to fall?”

text_8.eng: Jasu went to the market with her mother.

guidance_8_a.eng: Say, “Look, a girls seems to be going somewhere with her mother, I wonder where they could be going.”

text_9.eng: She kicked her ball.

guidance_9_a.eng:
Help your child learn new words. Say: “Look, there is a palm tree, a man riding a bicycle, a woman carrying a basket, mother running on sandals and a scuff flying off as the mother runs.” 

Then say: “ Show me a palm tree, show me a bicycle, show me a basket, show me a pair of sandals and show me a scuff”

text_10.eng: It landed in a basket of tomatoes. Tomatoes fell to the ground!

guidance_10_a.eng:
Say, “Oh no, tomatoes fell on the ground.” Ask, “How many tomatoes are on the ground? What color are they? Have you seen tomatoes before? Where have you seen them?” 

Ask, “How do you think the woman whose tomatoes fell off is feeling? How would you feel if your favourite food fell off?”

text_11.eng: Mama told Jasu not to play around. Jasu apologized again.

guidance_11_a.eng:
Ask the child to name the fruits and vegetables in the picture. Point at the different fruits and vegetables and say, “what do we call this fruit? What do we call these vegetables?” 

Then point at different fruits and vegetables in the picture and ask the child to name colors. Ask, “What color is this?”

Then ask, “Which is your favourite fruit? Which is your favourite vegetable?”

text_12.eng: Jasu carried her ball all the way home.

guidance_12_a.eng:
Say, “Look, the girl and the mother are walking home from the markert.”

Ask, “what is the girl carrying in her hands? How many items are in the mothers basket? What colors are they?

Say, “Look at the child and Mommy” and ask, "Can you see anything that looks the same on the child and Mommy's clothes and shoes?"

text_13.eng: At home, Jasu went to the playground with her friends. They played happily.

guidance_13_a.eng: Say, “Look, the girl is now home with her friends and they are ready to play together.” Ask, “do you have friends that you play with? How many friends do you have? Are they boys or girls?

text_14.eng: Grandpa was happy that Jasu is playing in a safe place. He bought Jasu a nice new ball. Every evening, the neighborhood kids gathered to play at the playground.

guidance_14_a.eng: Say, “Look, there is grandpa, I think he is watching the girl and her friends as they play together. Ask, “how do you think the kids feel? How do you feel when you play with your friends?

text_15.eng: Jasu likes kicking the new ball with her friends...

guidance_15_a.eng:
Say, “Wow, I wonder if the playground is near their house? If it is, grandpa can watch them and they will be safe”

Ask, “Do you also play with your friends close to your house too?”

text_16.eng: ...but Jasu still loves her old ball, too.

guidance_16_a.eng: Say, “Now tell me, what do you think of this story? Do you like it? If not, why don't you like it?”

rows.author: Jacqui L’Ange
rows.title: Shongololo's Shoes

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover. Ask: What do you see? Where is the millipede shongololo sitting?

description.eng: Shongololo has lost his shoes, and the other animals are NOT being very helpful. Will he ever find them?

licence.eng: © Book Dash, 2016. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: Where are all my shoes? I know I left them here!

guidance_1_a.eng: Use descriptive words and explanations to talk about the pictures. The long millipede has many tiny little feet. I think he is looking for his shoes. I see some yellow boots scattered across the floor. Do you think those are his shoes?

text_2.eng: I haven’t seen your shoes. Go ask Snail!

guidance_2_a.eng: Ask your child questions to help them think about what is happening. Ask: What is he holding in his hand? Who do you think that belongs to?

text_3.eng: No shoes here. Go ask Giraffe.

guidance_3_a.eng: To help your child understand, explain what is happening. Say: Look, the snail is using one of the millipede’s shoes as a shell for his back. Ask: how do you think the shongololo feels about that?

text_4.eng: I’m in a hurry – go ask Frog.

guidance_4_a.eng: Ask: What does the giraffe have on her head? What is she doing? Can you count all her spots?

text_5.eng: Shoes? How many? Go ask Flamingo.

guidance_5_a.eng: Ask: Where is the frog sitting? What colours can you see in this picture?

text_6.eng: Seen your shoes? No, not me.

guidance_6_a.eng: Mimic actions from the story. Say: Look, the flamingo is standing on one leg. Can you stand on one leg like flamingo?

text_7.eng: Will I ever find my shoes?

guidance_7_a.eng: Talk about what the characters might be thinking or feeling. Ask: how does he feel? Why do you think he feels that way?

text_8.eng: Shoes, eh? You should ask the Monkeys.

guidance_8_a.eng: Ask: What is the fox using the shoe for? What do you think is in the shoe? Would you drink something out of a shoe?

text_9.eng: Hello hello? We’re busy. Go ask Owl, she knows everything!

guidance_9_a.eng: Use a lively, playful voice, with different voices for different characters. Pretend to be the monkeys talking to each other in funny voices.

text_10.eng: Hmm. I have an idea. Why don’t you ask Lion?

guidance_10_a.eng: Connect what is happening in the book with your child’s experiences. Say: Look, the owl is reading a book, just like us. What are some of your favourite books or stories?

text_11.eng: These are yours? I’ll give them all back if you come to my party!

guidance_11_a.eng: Ask: what does the lion have in his hair? How many shoes can you see? Which of all the animals has the most shoes?

guidance_12_a.eng: Use the pictures to help your child practice counting. You can ask your child to count, or count out loud for your child. Say: how many animals are there? And how many flags? Can you count all of Shongololo's yellow shoes?

guidance_13_a.eng: Act out events from the book at a later stage. You can hide shoes around the house for your child to try and find. Think of funny or creative places to hide the shoes!

rows.author: Rayhaanah Williams
rows.title: What’s next?

description.eng: Once the school bell rings, the excitement begins. Grandpa picks Fatima up from school. What adventures will they have?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1.eng: Fatima is always busy! She loves to run and play.

text_2.eng: Her favourite part of the day is when Grandpa arrives. "How should we spend our day, Fatima?" asks Grandpa.

text_3_left.eng: "I know!" says Fatima. "Let’s go to the park."

text_3_right.eng: "I can see the whole world from up here," Fatima shouts.

text_4.eng: "I have an idea!" "Let’s play superheroes and pick up the litter," says Fatima.

text_5.eng: "Great stuff! Now you can see all the flowers." "What’s next?" asks Grandpa.

text_6.eng: "Weeeeeeeee!" "What a crazy cool kid you are!" says Grandpa. "What’s next?"

text_7.eng: "How about something cold and delicious?" says Fatima.

text_8.eng: "What’s next, kiddo?" asks Grandpa. Fatima yawns. "Let’s go home."

text_10_left.eng: "Hello, Fatima," says Mum. "What did you and Grandpa do today?"

text_11.eng: "What should we do tomorrow?" asks Fatima.

text_12.eng: Fatima hurries to bed. She is excited for her next adventure with her best friend, Grandpa.

rows.title: SHHHHH!

description.eng: Shh! Baby is asleep! Why is everyone making so much noise?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1.eng: Baby is sleeping. zzzzzzzzzzzz

text_2.eng: DOOF DOOF! DOOF Shh, Sister! Baby is sleeping!

text_3.eng: CLANG CLANG CLANG! Shh, Brother! Baby is sleeping!

text_4.eng: WOOF WOOF WOOF! Shhh, dog! Baby is sleeping!

text_5.eng: Beepity Beep! Beepity Beep! Shhh, phone! Baby is sleeping!

text_6.eng: TOOT TOOT TEETOOT! Shhhh, radio! Baby is sleeping!

text_7.eng: Brmmm Brmmm BRMMM! Shhhhh, truck! Baby is sleeping!

text_8.eng: CLICKITY CLACK CLICKITY CLACK! Shhhhh, train! Baby is sleeping!

text_9.eng: Ba dubba dubba Dubba dubba! Shhhhhhhhh, helicopter! Baby is sleeping!

text_10.eng: Baby is awake!

text_11.eng: DOOF CLANG WOOF BEEP TOOT BRMMM CLICKITY BADUBBA

rows.author: Sam Beckbessinger
rows.title: Lost Toy

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: A child has lost their favorite toy. They are so sad. Will some kind strangers help?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

guidance_1_a.eng:
Describe what is happening in the picture and say, "Look over here! See the boy? He's holding his toy really close, like he loves it a lot!"
Ask, "Do you have toys? Do you love your toys too?"

guidance_2_a.eng: Say, “Oh no! It looks like the boy is crying. I wonder what could have happened. Perhaps he doesn't want to leave? Or maybe he forgot his toy? Hmmm…!

guidance_3_a.eng:
Say, “Look at the boy! He looks really, really sad. See that big cloud above his head? That's a thought bubble, like what he's thinking inside.”
Ask, "What do you think he's thinking about that makes him so sad? How can you tell he's feeling sad? What does your face look like when you are sad?"

guidance_4_a.eng: Describe the picture and say, “Oh no! The boy is really sad, he doesn't want to ride a taxi without his toy. Where could it have gone?”

guidance_5_a.eng: Point at the toy in the picture and say, “Look, is that the boy’s toy in that bag?  I wonder how it got there.

guidance_6_a.eng:
Say, “Wow, look what we have here. It is a market, they are selling so many things. Now let's explore them together.

Point at the different items and ask the child to name them. Ask, “what is this?” 

Then help the child to count by saying, “Now tell me, how many taxis do you see? How many fish are they selling? How many bundles of bananas do they have? How many people are there?”

guidance_7_a.eng: Act worried and sad then say, “Oh no, is the toy falling off the bag? Not again!”

guidance_8_a.eng:
Say, “Look, there is a dog bucking at the toy”. Mimic the sound of a bucking dog, then say, “I wonder if it will be able to catch the toy from falling onto the ground.”

Ask, “Do you have dogs at home or in your village? Do you like them? Why or why not?

guidance_9_a.eng: Say, “Wow, it looks like the dog was able to rescue the toy. What an amazing dog.”

guidance_10_a.eng:
Point at the items in the picture and say, “Now let's play a spotting game! Look at grandpa's clothes, this toy, and this dog. Can you find the same color on all of them?
Let's do it like this: "Grandpa has a white shirt. Look! The dog is also white!" Now you try! Find a color that's the same on grandpa, the toy, and the dog. What color did you find?

guidance_11_a.eng:
Say, “Look, is that grandpa with the toy. Did grandpa find the lost toy?”

Point at the boy and say, “Look at the boy, I wonder how he might be feeling seeing his toy.”

guidance_12_a.eng: Ask, “Now tell me, how do you think the boy feels now that he got his lost toy back? How would you feel if something you love got lost? Why?

rows.description: A child has lost their favorite toy. They are so sad. Will some kind strangers help?
rows.licence: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).
rows.guidance_cover: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?
rows.guidance_1_a:
Describe what is happening in the picture and say, "Look over here! See the boy? He's holding his toy really close, like he loves it a lot!"
Ask, "Do you have toys? Do you love your toys too?"
rows.guidance_2_a: Say, “Oh no! It looks like the boy is crying. I wonder what could have happened. Perhaps he doesn't want to leave? Or maybe he forgot his toy? Hmmm…!
rows.guidance_3_a:
Say, “Look at the boy! He looks really, really sad. See that big cloud above his head? That's a thought bubble, like what he's thinking inside.”
Ask, "What do you think he's thinking about that makes him so sad? How can you tell he's feeling sad? What does your face look like when you are sad?"
rows.guidance_4_a: Describe the picture and say, “Oh no! The boy is really sad, he doesn't want to ride a taxi without his toy. Where could it have gone?”
rows.guidance_5_a: Point at the toy in the picture and say, “Look, is that the boy’s toy in that bag?  I wonder how it got there.

rows.author: David Mann
rows.title: What’s at the Park?

description.eng: Zoey loves finding things in the park. One day, she gets a big surprise.

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1.eng: Down the road from Zoey’s house, there is a big, green park.

text_2.eng: Zoey is quite shy, but she loves to play in the park. Every day after school, Zoey and Granny go there to play.

text_3_left.eng: Granny needs glasses to see. But she can hear very well. Zoey is good at finding things. Even better than Granny!

text_4_left.eng: She can find birds and bugs.

text_5_left.eng: She can find the prettiest flowers and the tallest trees.

text_6_left.eng: And she’s very good at finding Granny’s secret sweets.

text_7_left.eng: “What’s that noise behind the tree?” asks Granny. “Does it sound like a bird?” asks Zoey. “No,” says Granny. “It sounds much bigger than a bird. Can you see what it is?”

text_8.eng: “It’s a dog!” says Zoey.

text_9.eng: “Phew!” says Granny. “This dog is very smelly!”

text_10.eng: The next day, Zoey comes home from school and packs her bag. “Are you ready to go to the park?” asks Granny. “Yes, please,” says Zoey. “Granny, look who’s outside!” says Zoey.

text_11_left.eng: “You found us!” says Zoey. “Now, let’s give you a bath.”

text_12_left.eng: And from that day on, Zoey, Granny and their new friend played in the park every day.

rows.author: Refilwe Nsibande
rows.title: Zibu and Zizo

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: Zibu and Zizo are twin brothers. They are similar, but different. Being different is not bad, it’s great.

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: Zibu and Zizo are twin brothers. ‘They look the same,’ people always say.

guidance_1_a.eng:
Describe the picture and say, “look, these are twin brothers, they look almost the same, like two peas in a pod. 

Then say, "But... hmm... look closely! Can you see anything that's a little bit different between them?"

text_2.eng: Mama buys them the same clothes. They go to the same school.

guidance_2_a.eng:
Say, “The two brothers are now going to school in their uniform.” 

Ask, “what is the color of their uniform?

text_3.eng: Zibu and Zizo both like banana bread.

guidance_3_a.eng: Ask, “can you tell me what is on the table? How many slices of bread do you see?

text_4_left.eng: Sometimes Zibu and Zizo say ... Hello!! ... at the same time.

guidance_4_a.eng:
Say, “look, one of them is waving his hand. Perhaps he is greeting someone” 

Ask, “show me how you greet people when you meet them.”

guidance_5_a.eng: Ask, “Tell me, what do you think the boy in this picture is doing?”

guidance_6_a.eng:
Ask, “What about this one? What do you think he is doing?”

Ask again, “can you tell me the number of pencils and brushes you can see on the floor.”

text_7_left.eng: Zibu likes to talk to people.

guidance_7_a.eng:
Ask, “Can you tell me what you think is happening in this picture.”

Then ask, “how many children can you see? Point at the different children and ask, “what is the color of their clothes?”

text_8_left.eng: Zizo likes to keep to himself.

guidance_8_a.eng: Say, “Look, the boy is reading a book. I wonder what he could be reading about?”

text_9_right.eng: Zibu likes counting numbers. He wants to be an accountant.

guidance_9_a.eng:
Say, "Look! So many numbers! The boy looks like he's counting them."
Ask, "Can you help me count the numbers? Let's see... how many numbers are red? Now, how many numbers are green? Let's now count the blue numbers. How many blue ones are there? Last one! Can you count how many numbers are yellow?”

text_10.eng: Zizo likes learning new words. He wants to write books.

guidance_10_a.eng:
Say, "Look! A pink book! And guess what's on the cover? A kitty! Mimic the cat sound and say, "Meow! Meow!" 
Then ask, "Can you try to make a kitty sound?"

text_11_left.eng: ‘How come Zibu and Zizo look the same, but like different things?’ ask the children at school.

guidance_11_a.eng: Describe the picture and say, "Look at these kids! They're looking at the twin brothers and thinking, 'Hmm, why do they like different things even though they look the same?'"

text_12_left.eng: We look the same, but we are different and like different things and that's okay.'

guidance_12_a.eng: Ask, "Do you think it's okay for twin brothers to like different things, like maybe one likes cars and the other likes blocks? Why do you think that?"

rows.author: Xolile Sepuru
rows.title: Yes you can!

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: Join Teacher Langa’s class as they share what they want to be when they grow up. Let’s see what they say!

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1.eng: “What do you want to be when you grow up?” asks Teacher Langa.

guidance_1_a.eng: Say: “Hmmm I can see lots of different children in this picture. They all look different and are doing different things. What do you see?”

text_2.eng: Khutso shouts, “I want to be a cook!”

guidance_2_a.eng: Ask: “What do you think is happening in this picture?” If the child is unable to explain the picture, help them to understand what is happening by saying, “the boy is thinking of becoming a chef when he grows up.”

text_3_right.eng: I love helping my mom bake and cook at home.” Nandi says, “No! That’s a girl’s job. My mom does all the cooking at home.” “Yes he can, Nandi. You can be anything you want to be,” says Teacher Langa. The class chants, “Yes you can!”

guidance_3_a.eng: Ask: What is different between this picture and the previous one? Something is falling on someone’s head - can you spot who? How do they feel?”

text_4.eng: Milani says, “I want to build houses like my dad.”

guidance_4_a.eng: Ask: “What is she thinking of becoming one day?”

text_5_right.eng: “No you can’t, that’s dangerous!” yells Phathu. “Yes she can, Phathu, as long as she loves it,” replies Teacher Langa. The class chants, “Yes she can!”

guidance_5_a.eng: Ask: “How many children are in this picture? And how many of them are on the ladder? And if two climbed off, how many would there be on the ladder then?”

text_6.eng: Sthelo says, “I want to be a nurse.”

guidance_6_a.eng: Say: “Look, the boy is thinking of becoming a nurse when he grows up.” Ask: “Would you like to become a nurse when you grow up? Why or why not?”

text_7_right.eng: The class bursts out laughing. “What is so funny?” asks Teacher Langa. Nandi replies, “Nurses are girls.” “There are male nurses too,” says Teacher Langa. “So class, can Sthelo be a nurse? The class booms, “Yes he can!”

guidance_7_a.eng: Ask: Why do you think other kids are laughing? Point to the child hanging on the pole and say: “How do you think he is feeling? Why do you think he is feeling that way? Do you think it is because the other children are saying he can’t be a nurse because he is a boy? Did you know that men and women can be nurses, just like men and women can be doctors?”

text_8.eng: “I want to be an artist and draw pretty pictures,’’ says Liyana.

guidance_8_a.eng: Ask: “What do you think this child wants to be when she grows up? What is she painting? How do you think she feels? Why does the woman in the picture look worried?”

text_9_right.eng: “That’s not a real job,” says Khutso and rolls his eyes. “That sounds lovely, Liyana!” replies teacher Langa. “Can Liyana be an artist?” “Yes she can!” shouts the class!

guidance_9_a.eng: Describe what the children are wearing, and compare the colours and clothes with what you and your child are wearing.

text_10.eng: “I want to be an alarm clock,” says Phathu.

guidance_10_a.eng: Say: “Hmmm, what does this child want to be? An alarm clock!? What do you think about that?”

text_11.eng: “Huh?” “What do you think, class?” asks Teacher Langa. The class booms, “Yes you can! Yes you can!”

guidance_11_a.eng: Ask: “Who has short hair in this picture? Who has long hair? And your hair? Is it short or long? And my hair?”

text_12.eng: Nandi hasn’t shared what she wants to be when she grows up. What do you think she could be?

guidance_12_a.eng: Ask: “What did you think of the story? What did you like about it? Do you know that you can be anything you want? Then say, “Yes you can!”

rows.author: Sanjana Kapur
rows.title: Yellow Earth, Brown Earth

description.eng: Avi is an explorer. A cloud-watcher, a seed-sorter and a puddle-splasher. Travel to Avi’s favourite place — the Earth — in this book about noticing and recognising patterns.

licence.eng: © Pratham Books, 2021. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: Avi wakes up early. It is a good day. Avi is visiting Yellow Earth today. Yellow flowers, dried-up flowers, tiny flowers. Yellow flowers—

text_2.eng: Avi looks for the perfect stick to poke the earth with. Smooth stick bumpy stick. Smooth stick—

text_3.eng: Avi collects seeds. Brown seeds, black seeds, red seeds, green seeds. Brown seeds, black seeds— Yellow Earth is a happy place.

text_4.eng: Avi is visiting Grey Earth today.

text_4_right.eng: Big puddle, small puddle, no puddle. Big puddle, small puddle—

text_5.eng: Drip! Drop! Plish! Drip—

text_5_right.eng: Grey Earth is a wet place.

text_6.eng: Avi is visiting Brown Earth today. CRUNCH crunch CRUNCH crunch—

text_6_right.eng: Avi stomps on the dry ground.

text_7.eng: Avi smiles at the bright sun. Long cloud, round cloud, thin cloud. Long cloud— Brown Earth is a joyful place.

text_8.eng: Avi watches the Earth change every year. Yellow Earth, Grey Earth, Brown Earth—

text_9_left.eng: Avi is looking for a stick.

text_10.eng: Patterns Are All Around Us The day, the week, the month and the year — all have patterns that repeat. The seasons change every year and come back the same way. Every year, winter is followed by summer, which is followed by the monsoon. Look around you and try to spot these patterns. Go back to the beginning of the book and look for patterns you might have missed.

rows.author: Roxana Bouwer
rows.title: Why is Nita Upside Down

description.eng: Nita’s hanging upside down. Can she turn the right way round?

licence.eng: Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: Nita’s hanging upside down, her long hair tickling at the ground. The trees, the grass, the everything is all the wrong way round.

text_2_left.eng: Her feet, they poke into the sky. Little Navi’s walking by. He says ‘I’ve seen you here before. You’re upside down again! What for?’

text_3_left.eng: His feet swim lightly in the air. She tries to hide behind her hair. ‘It’s h-h-h-hard to t-t-talk’, she says to him. ‘I’m not the same. I don’t fit in.’

text_4_left.eng: Navi takes her by the hand. He wants to help her understand. They climb to Navi’s look-out spot. From up here they can see a lot. They perch and have a quiet stare at children playing here and there.

text_6.eng: Those kids are not tthe same at all. Abe’s round.

text_7.eng: Chi’s freckled,

text_9.eng: Bambam’s wild and must be free,

text_10.eng: while Lulu’s reading quietly.

text_13_left.eng: And me, I am just skin and bone. And you are you. You’re not alone. Each human’s sort of strange, you see. That makes you just the same, like me. This world is really one big game. To play, we can’t all be the same.

text_14_left.eng: Nita feels the right way round, thanks to the new friend she’s found. Upside down was never fun. Now she plays with everyone.

rows.text_2_left: Her feet, they poke into the sky. Little Navi’s walking by. He says ‘I’ve seen you here before. You’re upside down again! What for?’
rows.text_3_left: His feet swim lightly in the air. She tries to hide behind her hair. ‘It’s h-h-h-hard to t-t-talk’, she says to him. ‘I’m not the same. I don’t fit in.’
rows.text_4_left: Navi takes her by the hand. He wants to help her understand. They climb to Navi’s look-out spot. From up here they can see a lot. They perch and have a quiet stare at children playing here and there.
rows.text_7: Chi’s freckled,
rows.text_9: Bambam’s wild and must be free,
rows.text_10: while Lulu’s reading quietly.
rows.text_1_left: Nita’s hanging upside down, her long hair tickling at the ground. The trees, the grass, the everything is all the wrong way round.
rows.text_6: Those kids are not tthe same at all. Abe’s round.
rows.text_13_left: And me, I am just skin and bone. And you are you. You’re not alone. Each human’s sort of strange, you see. That makes you just the same, like me. This world is really one big game. To play, we can’t all be the same.
rows.text_14_left: Nita feels the right way round, thanks to the new friend she’s found. Upside down was never fun. Now she plays with everyone.

rows.author: Michele Fry
rows.title: When I grow up

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover. Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: I don’t know what I want to be when I grow up. Can you help me choose?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

guidance_1_a.eng: You can say: Look, the girl is holding a big sunflower. What colour is the flower’s petals? And what colour is the stem? Have you ever seen such a big flower in real life?”

text_2.eng: What do I want to be when I grow up?

guidance_2_a.eng: Ask: “What is that? (mimic barking sounds). Ask your child to think about dogs they know: where have they seen them? What are they like?

guidance_3_a.eng: Say: “Wow, the girl is dancing.” Ask: How do you think the girl feels? Do you love to dance? How do you feel when you dance?”

text_4.eng: When I grow up, I want to be a dancer and dance on a stage.

guidance_4_a.eng: Ask: “How many ballet shoes can you see? What colors are they?”

guidance_5_a.eng: Describe the picture and say: “Look, there is a puppy with a Firefighter. The firefighter is holding a fire hose. He uses it to put out big fires.”

text_6.eng: When I grow up, I want to be a firefighter and put out big fires.

guidance_6_a.eng: Ask: “Would you like to be a firefighter? Why or Why not?”

text_7.eng: When I grow up, I want to be a nurse and make sick people better.

guidance_7_a.eng: Say: “Look now she is a nurse”. Ask: Have you seen a nurse before? Where did you see a nurse? Would you like to be a nurse or a doctor? Why or why not?”

guidance_8_a.eng: Say: “Wow, there is a teddy with a nurse. I wonder how he is feeling.” Ask: “How do you think a teddy is feeling? Why do you think he is feeling that way?”

text_9_right.eng: When I grow up, I want to be a musician and play in a band.

guidance_9_a.eng: Say: “Ohhh, the girl is holding a guitar. I think she is a musician.” Ask: “Do you love music? What songs do you like?”

guidance_10_a.eng: Describe and explain what you see in the picture. Point to the spanner and say: “this is a spanner. A spanner is used to grip, tighten or loosen screws and nails.” (mimic the action of using a spanner). This will help a child to learn new words “grip”, “tighten” and “loosen”.

text_11.eng: When I grow up, I want to be a mechanic and fix cars and tractors.

guidance_11_a.eng: Say: “Spanners are used by mechanics to fix cars and other vehicles.” Ask: “Where on this car do you think we can use a spanner?”

guidance_12_a.eng:
Say: “Look, she is writing down letters from the alphabet on the board”. Ask: Can you recognise any of these letters? Say: “Let’s sing the alphabet song together - A, B, C, D, E, F, G….”  

You can also point to the different letters and name different words that start with that letter.

text_13.eng: When I grow up, I want to be a teacher and teach children to read and write.

guidance_13_a.eng: Ask: “Does your teacher also write on the board at school? What do you like most about school? And what don’t you like?”

guidance_14_a.eng: Say: “Look - now she is wearing a soccer outfit.” Ask: “What colour are her pants? What colours are her socks? And What colours are her shoes?”

text_15.eng: When I grow up, I want to be a soccer player and score the winning goal.

guidance_15_a.eng: Say: “Here is a soccer ball.” Ask: “What colours are the ball? What shape is the ball? What can you see here at home that is the same shape?”

text_16.eng: When I grow up, I want to be an astronaut and fly to the moon.

guidance_16_a.eng: Say: “Look, there is the moon, and here are more planets! Do you know how to get to the moon? You have to be an astronaut.”

guidance_17_a.eng:
Say: “What is an astronaut? An astronaut is a person who is trained to travel to space. They travel to space in a spacecraft. A spacecraft is a vehicle that is designed to fly and operate in outer space. How cool is that?”

Ask: “Would you like to go to space? Why or why not?”

guidance_18_a.eng:
Say: “Now she is a chef. She cooks delicious food for everyone.”

Make links between the pictures and your child’s world. Ask: “Who cooks for you at home? Do you like making food, or helping to prepare our meals?”

text_19.eng: When I grow up, I want to be a chef and make food for my family and friends.

guidance_19_a.eng: Say: “Hmmmm. Those biscuits look delicious” (and mimic smelling the biscuits or making eating sounds). Ask: “Do you love biscuits? Can you count the number of biscuits in the picture? What colors and shapes are these biscuits?”

guidance_20_a.eng:
Ask or say: “What is the girl thinking about? Perhaps she is thinking about what she wants to be when she grows up.”

Say (while pointing to each thought): “perhaps she is deciding whether she wants to be a dancer…or an astronaut…., or a teacher one day?”

text_21.eng: When I grow up, I can choose whatever I want to be!

text_22.eng: What do you want to be when you grow up?

guidance_22_a.eng: Ask: “What would you want to be when you grow up? Why?”

guidance_23_a.eng: Ask: Which of these items have you seen at home, outside, or in our community? Which one is your favourite and why?”

guidance_24_a.eng:
Ask: “What do you think about this story?”

Then say: “Do you know that there are many different things that you can be when you grow up? How exciting!”

rows.author: Crystal Warren
rows.title: What's In The Pot?

description.eng: Sam can’t wait for supper. What’s in the pot? Wait and see.

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1.eng: “What’s for supper?” asked Sam. “It’s a surprise”, said Mama, putting a big pot on the stove.

text_2_right.eng: She added a jug of water. Sam was worried. “Are we having water for supper?” he wailed. “It’s a surprise. Wait and see.” replied Mama.

text_3.eng: “Can I help?” asked Sam. “I could stir.”

text_3_left.eng: “You are still a bit short,” said Mama. “The pot might fall over. But you can help me by fetching things.”

text_4.eng: "Can you bring me an onoin, please." "This doesn't smell very nice."

text_4_right.eng: "They will taste nice once they are cooked."

text_5_left.eng: “Now I need some tomatoes. No, that is an apple. The tomatoes are also round and red, but you will find them in the fridge.”

text_6.eng: “Can you bring me potatoes. They are round and brown.”

text_7.eng: “If you are hungry you can eat the apple while you wait.” “What about these?” “No, we won’t need biscuits. We can save those for after supper.”

text_8.eng: “What’s in the pot?”

text_9.eng: “What about this?” “That is a watermelon. It will be too big for the pot.” “See if you can find some spinach. It is also green.”

text_10.eng: “Please get some bread. No, it won’t go into the pot but on the table.”

text_11.eng: Mama carried the pot to the table and started to dish up. “What’s in the pot?” asked Sam.

text_12.eng: “Soup!” My favourite!

rows.author: Laura de Lange
rows.title: Tlotlego's Tea Party

description.eng: Tlotlego is hosting a tea party! But something strange keeps happening while he is setting the table.

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1.eng: Tlotlego is hosting a tea party for the WHOLE family. “How many people are coming for tea, Koko?” “You, me, Mama, and Papa. And your little sister, Tshiamo.”

text_2.eng: Tlotlego counts the teacups as he takes them from the kitchen. “One, two, three, four, and one for Koko!”

text_3.eng: Tlotlego goes to the stoep and places the teacups down on the table. “One, two, three, four, and ... ?” “I only see four cups,” says Koko, “but we are five people.” “When I was in the kitchen before, there were five cups!” Tlotlego exclaims.

text_4.eng: Tlotlego counts the pretty little plates as he takes them from the cupboard. “One, two, three, four, and five! There’s a plate for each of us.”

text_5.eng: Tlotlego goes to the stoep and places the plates next to the teacups.“One, two, three, four, and ... ?” “I only see four plates,” says Koko, “but we are five people.”

text_6.eng: Tlotlego counts the biscuits as he takes them from the jar. “One, two, three, four, and five!”

text_7.eng: Tlotlego goes to the stoep and places the biscuits on the plates.

text_7_right.eng: “One, two, three, four, and ... ?” “I only see four biscuits,” says Koko, “but we are five people.”

text_8.eng: Tlotlego is very confused. He knows he has been counting correctly. Before he had five biscuits, and now there are only four. HOW did the biscuits become less?

text_9.eng: Tlotlego counts the sugar cubes as he takes them from the jar. “One, two, three, four, and five!”

text_10.eng: Tlotlego goes to the stoep and places the sugar cubes on the table. This time, he is sure he hears a giggle. “One, two, three, four, and ... ?” “Five!” shouts a voice from under the table.

text_11.eng: Tlotlego bends down to look under the table. To his shock, he sees a complete tea set laid out under the table! There are the missing teacup, plate, biscuit, and sugar cube. FIVE!

text_12.eng: When Mama and Papa come home from work, they all have tea on the stoep. One, two, three of them having tea at the table, and two of them having tea below!

rows.author: Kirsty Paxton
rows.title: The one on the middle

description.eng: Khanyiswa is not the first born. She’s not the last born. She’s the one in the MIDDLE!

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: I am the middle one. Not the first born. Not the last born. The one in the middle!

text_2.eng: The one in the middle can be easy to forget.

text_3.eng: And easy to leave out.

text_4.eng: But that’s okay because I am also the one with IDEAS!

text_5.eng: Look what I can make from just this cardboard box! A BEAUTIFUL house... with real doors and windows.

text_7_right.eng: My house has an extra special bed, and a MAGIC SLIDE.

text_8_right.eng: Some days my house is also a shop.

text_9_left.eng: And on other days it’s a VERY FANTASTIC show.

text_10_right.eng: Sometimes my house is just for me!

text_11.eng: And that’s the best place for me.

text_11_left.eng: And sometimes it’s a house for three! I am the middle one. Not the first born. Not the last born. The one in the middle!

rows.author: Melissa Fagan
rows.title: The best thing ever

description.eng: Muzi loves to build with his toys. But when he leaves them behind to travel to uGogo’s house, he discovers something very special about the world. And he learns something new about himself.

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_right.eng: Muzi loves to build things. He dreams of building the best thing ever.

text_2.eng: Once he built a shelter for his toys. But it wasn’t the best thing ever.

text_3.eng: Yesterday he built a bridge for his animals. It was a good thing. But not the best...

text_4.eng: Today Muzi is going to visit uGogo. He is sad. Without his toys, how can he build the best thing ever?

text_5.eng: At the bus stop, Muzi is amazed. He sees red things and blue things. Small things and big things. New things and old things.

text_6_right.eng: Muzi has a new idea for building the best thing ever.

text_7.eng: On the road to uGogo’s, Muzi finds many things. Long things and short things. Round things and square things.

text_8.eng: By the riverside, Muzi finds more things. Soft things and pointy things. Green things and brown things.

text_10_right.eng: While uGogo bakes for the hungry travellers... Muzi builds.

text_11_right.eng: Gogo, Gogo! says Muzi. The world is full of toys. Look what I can build.

text_12_right.eng: Oh, Muzi, laughs Gogo. A new house for me. This is the best thing ever!

rows.author: Sope Martins
rows.title: Teju's Shadow

description.eng: Teju is worried. Something keeps following him! What could it be?

licence.eng: © Book Dash, 2019. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: “What’s that?”

text_2.eng: Teju hides. “It won’t find me here!”

text_3.eng: He runs. “Why are you following me?”

text_4.eng: Leave me ALONE!

text_5.eng: Go away. Go away.GO AWAY! “Teju! What are you doing?” “It won’t go away!” “Your shadow?”

text_6.eng: “It follows me everywhere! It’s like a super secret spy!”

text_7.eng: “Well, there’s one way to make a shadow disappear...”

text_8.eng: MAMA!

text_9.eng: Later that night in Teju’s bedroom, the light goes off...  ...and then on. And off... ...and on. Teju can’t sleep.

text_10.eng: <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>

text_11.eng: “What’s wrong Teju?” “It only goes away in the dark, but I’m scared of the dark!” Mum gives Teju a big hug. “Do you want to see something amazing?”

text_12.eng: OOOHHHH! AAAAHH!

text_12_right.eng: Mum and Teju make shadow puppets until he falls asleep.

text_13.eng: “Cool!” After school, Teju waits for Mum. “I’m bored.” Teju stands up, he jumps, he dances.His shadow does the same.

text_14.eng: When he goes to bed that night, Teju leaves his night Light on. “Goodnight Shadow!”

rows.text_9: Later that night in Teju’s bedroom, the light goes off...  ...and then on. And off... ...and on. Teju can’t sleep.

rows.author: Sanjana Kapur
rows.title: Paint Dat, Plant Day

description.eng: Avi enjoys plant day, music day and paint day, and being busy throughout the week. Join in as Avi potters about the house, in this book about noticing and recognising patterns.

licence.eng: © Pratham Books, 2021. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1_right.eng: Avi stretches and jumps out of bed. Today is Plant Day.

text_2.eng: Mama takes out the seeds. Avi places them carefully in the pots. Small pot, tall pot, square pot. Small pot— Avi waters the plants.

text_3.eng: Avi washes the brushes. Papa mixes the paints. Today is Paint Day. Swish, dip, squash, swirl. Swish, dip— Avi loves mixing the colours.

text_4.eng: Today is Fixing Day. Mama and Avi tighten the screws on the table. Tighten, thamp! Tighten, thamp! Avi checks to see if the table is still wobbly.

text_5.eng: Today is Cleaning Day. Avi helps Mama and Papa dust everything. Dhup, wipe, cough, clean. Dhup, wipe— ACHOO!

text_6.eng: Today is Sheet Day. Avi is changing the sheets on the beds. Pull, tuck, pull, tuck, pat-pat. Pull, tuck—

text_7.eng: Avi lines up all the cushions and pillows on the floor. Cushion, cushion, pillow, bolster. Cushion, cushion— JUMP!

text_8.eng: Music Day is Avi’s favourite. No one stops the loud sounds! Dham-dhoom- japh, dham- dhoom- japh. Avi hits the drums again. Dham—

text_9.eng: It is Bird Day. Avi watches the birds with Mama and Papa. Brown bird, slow-walker, long legs. Brown bird—

text_10.eng: Avi yawns. He is tired but excited about waking up in the morning. Tomorrow is Plant Day again!

text_11.eng: Patterns Are All Around Us. The days, the weeks, the months, and the years always follow a pattern. Look at the days in your week. Is any day kept for a special activity? Make a calendar for yourself and fill it with the patterns you see.

rows.author: Sally Partridge
rows.title: Mama, What's For Lunch

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: Join Thabo and his sister Tumi for magical lunches with Mama!

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1.eng: “Hurry,Thabo. Mama is making lunch,” calls Tumi.

guidance_1_a.eng: Ask your child to describe the picture: “What is the girl doing? What else is happening?”

guidance_2_a.eng: Ask your child: “What do you think the boy is doing? Why do you think the boy is doing that?”

text_3.eng: His friends don’t understand why he chooses lunch over their game, but Thabo has a secret. Mama’s lunches are special.

guidance_3_a.eng: Point to the boy and ask: “How do you think the boy is feeling? What do you think he is going to do next? Can you also describe the feelings of the other children, how do you think they feel?”

text_4_right.eng: On Monday, Mama shapes their food like little bugs that wriggle and crawl, making Tumi shriek in fright. “EEEE!” But they are yummy fruit and vegetables, and not very scary at all.

guidance_4_a.eng: Point to different images and ask your child to name them. You can ask: “How did they make those shapes out of the food? What foods are red? And what food is green?”

text_5.eng: On Tuesday, she makes a lion that roars so loudly the house shakes. “ROAR!” ut it’s just delicious pasta and cheese.

guidance_5_a.eng:
Use descriptive words and explanations to talk about pictures. This helps your child learn new words. “Look, they have created a roaring lion out of the pasta and cheese.”

Then mimic the sound of the roaring lion.

text_6_right.eng: On Wednesday, Mama creates a chicken that wakes up the whole street. “CLUCK CLUCK PAKAA!” But it’s just a plate of juicy fruit.

guidance_6_a.eng:
Point to the image and ask your child what the picture looks like. You can ask: “What animal did they make? (mimic the sound of a chicken). What did they use for the chicken’s tail? And what did they use for its beak?” 

You can ask: Have you seen chickens in our area?

text_7_right.eng: On Thursday, she builds a noisy truck. Thabo and Tumi cover their ears. “VROOOM!” But it’s a sweet strawberry jam sandwich.

guidance_7_a.eng: Ask: What did they make here? What did they use to make it? Then say, “oh no! that’s a noisy truck, let's cover our ears.”

text_8_right.eng: On Friday, Mama makes a beautiful garden filled with flowers, birds and ladybugs. “TWEET TWEET!” But it’s healthy pap, beans and a crunchy salad

guidance_8_a.eng: Ask: “How many insects can you see? And how many trees can you see? What colors are the leaves on the trees? Are they all the same shape?”

text_9_right.eng: “Mama, what’s for lunch?” asks Tumi. “Yes, Mama,” says Thabo. “What are you making today?”

guidance_9_a.eng: Ask: “How many people are sitting down and how many are standing? What can you see that is blue? And what can you see that is pink?”

text_10_right.eng: Thabo and Tumi can’t wait another second. Their tummies are grumbling. Finally, Mama is ready. “What is it Mama?” asks Thabo, licking his lips.

guidance_10_a.eng: Ask: “Why do you think the boy is licking his lips? What do you do when you are hungry?”

text_11_right.eng: It’s Thabo, Tumi and Mama! “Mmm, our favourite, your famous stew and rice.” “Thank you, Mama!”

guidance_11_a.eng: Say: “Yey, the food is finally ready!” Ask: How many dishes can you see? How many people do you think are going to eat? How do you think the boy is feeling now that the food is ready? How do you normally feel when you are given food?”

text_12_right.eng: What will Mama make on Sunday?

guidance_12_a.eng:
Ask: “Can you name the different foods in the picture? What food do you like? And what food don’t you like?

Let’s go to the kitchen and cut up some food into interesting shapes like they did in the story!”

rows.author: Sue Adams
rows.title: Let's go on a litter hunt

title.eng: Let's go on a litter hunt

description.eng: The yard is a mess. How will the children clean up?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: Papa says, “This yard is a MESS. The wind blew the rubbish in.” Mama says, “Let’s go on a litter hunt. First look for tins.” Papa says, “Wear these gloves.” Yuck!

text_2_left.eng: We’re going on a tin hunt. We look up high and down low. We look under the bushes and against the fence.

text_3.eng: We’ve found red tins and green tins, rusty tins and shiny tins, clean tins and dirty tins. Yuck!

text_4.eng: What must we do with all these tins? Find a bin and put them in! Now look for plastic.

text_5_left.eng: We’re going on a plastic hunt. We look up high and down low. We look behind the chicken coop and in front of the house.

text_6.eng: We’ve found milk bottles and bottle tops, shopping bags and sucker sticks, straws and broken buckets. Yuck!

text_7.eng: What must we do with all this plastic? Find a bin and put it in! Now look for paper.

text_8_left.eng: We’re going on a paper hunt. We look up high and down low. We look near the water barrel and on top of the bench.

text_9.eng: We’ve found wet paper and dry paper, cardboard boxes and newspaper, old paper plates and dirty tissues. Yuck!

text_10.eng: What must we do with all this paper? Find a bin and put it in! What else can you look for? Hmm ...

text_11.eng: There’s no more mess! Wow! This place is so clean. Thanks, litter hunters.

text_12.eng: You deserve a treat! And remember ... what must you do with your litter? Find a bin and put it in!

rows.author: Diane Awerbuck
rows.title: How do you sleep?

description.eng: Can you sleep with one eye open? Can you sleep in a tree? Pula has a bed, but he wants to know how other creatures sleep.

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_2.eng: How do you sleep, bird? I fly in my sleep

text_3.eng: How do you sleep, bat? I sleep upside down.

text_4.eng: How do you sleep, bullfrog? I rest on my side

text_5.eng: How do you sleep, octopus? I change colour in my dreams.

text_6.eng: How do you sleep, duck? We take turns to guard each other.

text_7.eng: How do you sleep, baby owl? I sleep on my face.

text_8.eng: How do you sleep, otter? We sleep holding hands.

text_9.eng: How do you sleep, walrus? I sleep on the land and under the water.

text_10.eng: How do you sleep, giraffe? We sleep on each other.

text_11.eng: How do you sleep, meerkat? We sleep in a heap.

text_12.eng: How do you sleep, Pula? Good night! Sleep tight!

rows.author: Matthew Kalil
rows.title: Grandpa Farouk’s garden

description.eng: Amir loves Grandpa Farouk’s garden. But it’s dying. What can Amir do to help?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_right.eng: Deep in the city, surrounded by houses and bricks and tar, you’ll find Grandpa Farouk’s garden.

text_2_left.eng: Amir visits Grandpa once a week. He loves the leaves and flowers and trees.

text_3.eng: Amir helps to water the plants. He helps with the compost, and works with his Grandpa all day.

text_4.eng: When they finish, they feast on a harvest of fruit. One day, Grandpa didn’t eat his pear. “What’s wrong?” asked Amir.

text_5_left.eng: “My garden is dying,” replied Grandpa. “Why?” asked Amir. “Look closely,” said Grandpa. “Some pests are eating the plants.”

text_6.eng: “We need ladybirds!” said Grandpa. “They are the bugs that eat the pests that kill the plants. Without ladybirds, the garden will die.” “I’ll bring you a bug or two,” said Amir.

text_7.eng: For a whole week, Amir looked and searched and collected. He found one ladybird on the sports field.

text_8.eng: Two more at the shop. Three at the park.

text_9.eng: And four behind the TV. Next week, Amir went to visit Grandpa Farouk, and showed him his jar of ten bugs. “You’ve done well, oh my boy, you’ve done well,” Grandpa said, with a tear in his eye.

text_10_left.eng: Grandpa was very happy. The ladybirds were very hungry!

text_11.eng: The ladybirds ate the pests, and the garden blossomed.

text_12_right.eng: From that day on, Grandpa Farouk’s garden did what gardens should do. It grew and grew and grew.

rows.author: Marion Drew
rows.title: Lefa's Bath

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: Lefa wants her bath, but where does all the water go?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

guidance_1_a.eng: Ask your child: what is the girl doing? Why do you think she is doing that? What animals are those? How many are there?

guidance_2_a.eng: Mimic sounds and actions from the story, like the cows drinking the water.

guidance_3_a.eng: Say: oh no! Where has all the water gone? How do you think the girl is feeling?

guidance_4_a.eng: Use descriptive words to talk about the pictures. Say: she is pouring water from her yellow bucket into the large orange bath.

guidance_5_a.eng: Say: look! The ducks are splashing in the water! What do you think will happen next?

guidance_6_a.eng: Say: oh no! The bath has been emptied again! How did that happen? How is the girl feeling now?

guidance_7_a.eng: Ask: What is the girl doing now? What animal can we see coming closer?

guidance_8_a.eng: Ask your child: What is the pig doing? What is happening to the water? Can the girl see what is happening?

guidance_9_a.eng: Say: oh no! What happened to the bath now? How is the girl feeling?

guidance_10_a.eng: Use your voice and face to demonstrate emotions from the pictures. Say: look, she is crying? Why do you think she is feeling sad? How do you think the animals are feeling?

guidance_11_a.eng: Ask: what are the animals doing? Why are they doing that? Say: Can you count the buckets of water? Are they all the same colour? What colours can you see?

guidance_12_a.eng: Ask: How do you think the girl is feeling now? Why?

guidance_13_a.eng: Reflect on the story with your child. Ask: What did you think about the story? How would you feel if you were in the story? What would you have done?

rows.guidance_3_a: Say: oh no! Where has all the water gone? How do you think the girl is feeling?
rows.guidance_4_a: Use descriptive words to talk about the pictures. Say: she is pouring water from her yellow bucket into the large orange bath.
rows.guidance_5_a: Say: look! The ducks are splashing in the water! What do you think will happen next?
rows.guidance_6_a: Say: oh no! The bath has been emptied again! How did that happen? How is the girl feeling now?
rows.guidance_7_a: Ask: What is the girl doing now? What animal can we see coming closer?
rows.guidance_8_a: Ask your child: What is the pig doing? What is happening to the water? Can the girl see what is happening?
rows.guidance_9_a: Say: oh no! What happened to the bath now? How is the girl feeling?
rows.guidance_10_a: Use your voice and face to demonstrate emotions from the pictures. Say: look, she is crying? Why do you think she is feeling sad? How do you think the animals are feeling?
rows.guidance_11_a: Ask: what are the animals doing? Why are they doing that? Say: Can you count the buckets of water? Are they all the same colour? What colours can you see?
rows.guidance_12_a: Ask: How do you think the girl is feeling now? Why?
rows.guidance_13_a: Reflect on the story with your child. Ask: What did you think about the story? How would you feel if you were in the story? What would you have done?
